title.en-US: Improving Inventory Performance in Food & Beverage Supply Chains Using Decision Intelligence

content.en-US:
![AdobeStock 969227653](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/6IK14URfbkKQ8GoJ4dFqFV/1b4e1198641aea3ae4a267f8f721d32b/AdobeStock_969227653.jpg)

This blog is the first in a five-part series of posts on transforming food and beverage supply chain operations with Aera, the decision intelligence agent.

The food and beverage (F&B) industry is undergoing profound transformations, grappling with a convergence of challenges that demand innovative solutions. Shifting consumer expectations for personalized, transparent, and sustainable products has added complexity to supply chain management. These challenges are exacerbated by rising costs of raw materials, transportation, and labor, as well as frequent disruptions in global supply chains. Amid these pressures, inventory performance has emerged as a critical focal point for F&B companies striving to maintain operational excellence. ### The Inventory Challenges of F&B Supply Chains Balancing inventory effectively ensuring that stock is sufficient to meet demand without overstocking is a perennial challenge for F&B companies. Mismanagement of inventory can lead to severe, costly consequences: - __Spoilage:__ Excess inventory often results in perishable items expiring before they can be sold, leading to waste and financial loss. - __Tied-Up Capital:__ Overstocking ties up valuable financial resources that could otherwise be directed toward growth initiatives or operational improvements. - __Markdowns:__ Surplus inventory frequently necessitates price reductions, eroding profitability and brand equity. Traditional inventory management approaches frequently fall short in addressing the complexities of modern supply chains. These legacy systems and methods are often hindered by a lack of real-time visibility into inventory levels, making it difficult for companies to respond quickly to shifting demand patterns. Additionally, many businesses continue to rely heavily on manual processes, which are inherently prone to human error and inefficiency. This reliance not only slows decision-making but also increases the likelihood of costly mistakes. Predicting demand fluctuations is another major hurdle, as traditional systems struggle to integrate and analyze the diverse range of data sources required for accurate forecasting. Furthermore, these outdated approaches are ill-equipped to manage the unique challenges of perishable goods. Without precise tools, companies frequently grapple with both overstocking and understocking, leading to higher rates of spoilage, missed sales opportunities, and overall inefficiency. These limitations underscore the need for a more advanced, data-driven approach to inventory management. ### Aera: Revolutionizing Inventory Performance with Decision Intelligence Aera, the decision intelligence agent, empowers F&B companies to navigate these challenges with confidence. By harnessing the power of artificial intelligence (AI) and automation, the agent delivers smarter, faster, and more impactful decisions. At the heart of this innovation lies decision intelligence, which transforms inventory management into a proactive, optimized process. Several advanced skills help to optimize inventory performance in real time: 1. __Control Tower__ provides real-time visibility into inventory levels and movements, enabling quick, informed decision-making to address potential issues before they escalate. 2. __Demand Forecasting__ uses historical data and external inputs to generate accurate forecasts, ensuring that inventory aligns with anticipated needs. 3. __Demand Sensing__ incorporates real-time signals such as point-of-sale (POS) data and weather trends to refine forecasts and adapt to sudden demand shifts, enhancing responsiveness. 4. __Dynamic Safety Stock Adjustments__ continuously recalibrate stock levels based on real-time demand variability and supply chain conditions, optimizing inventory buffers. 5. __Inventory Rebalancing__ dynamically redistributes inventory across locations, preventing overstocking in some areas and stockouts in others. 6. __Aging Inventory Management__ identifies at-risk inventory and suggests redistributive actions to reduce spoilage and minimize financial write-offs. By leveraging these skills, F&B companies can achieve measurable improvements in inventory performance: - __Reduced Spoilage and Waste:__ Efficient management of perishable goods can reduce waste by 20-30%. - __Optimized Stock Levels:__ Improved inventory balancing frees up 5-10% of working capital by avoiding overstocking. - __Enhanced Service Levels:__ Proactively managing inventory prevents stockouts, ensuring 5-10% better product availability when and where customers need it. ### A Real-World Success Story One global leader in the food and beverage industry turned to Aera to address chronic inventory challenges. The company faced difficulties in forecasting demand across its extensive portfolio of SKUs and markets. Traditional tools, reliant on static models and siloed data, were unable to process the vast amounts of POS and external signals. This led to frequent stockouts, overstocking, and strained relationships with retail partners. By deploying Aeras Demand Sensing Skill, the company operationalized AI to analyze diverse datasets, including POS data, economic indicators, and weather forecasts. Advanced machine learning models provided actionable, real-time insights that significantly improved planning accuracy. The impact was transformative, including the following achievements: - __$20M Saved:__ Decisions previously left unactioned were now optimized, yielding substantial savings. - __4-13% Improvement in Forecast Accuracy:__ Enhanced precision in sell-out forecasts. - __25% Reduction in Planner Workload:__ Automation and AI reduced manual planning efforts. - __98% Fill Rate and 97% On-Shelf Availability:__ Improved stock availability ensured customer satisfaction. - __2-5 Hours Saved Per Forecast Cycle:__ Key markets experienced faster, more efficient forecasting processes. By transforming demand forecasting from a reactive process into a proactive capability, the agent not only reduced costs but also laid the groundwork for improved retailer collaboration and global scalability. ### The Future of Inventory Management The food and beverage industrys success hinges on the ability to navigate supply chain complexities with agility and precision. Aeras AI-driven capabilities empower companies to transform inventory performance into a competitive advantage. By leveraging decision intelligence, F&B organizations can reduce waste, enhance profitability, and deliver superior customer experiencesall while adapting to the evolving demands of a dynamic market.

As challenges continue to mount, solutions like Aera prove that with the right tools, companies can turn obstacles into opportunities, ensuring long-term success in an ever-changing landscape. For further details on how Aera can transform your F&B supply chain, download the whitepaper, The AI Recipe for the Future of Food and Beverage Supply Chains.

title.en-US: Reducing Waste in Food & Beverage Supply Chains Using Decision Intelligence

content.en-US:
![AdobeStock 1073034514](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/4tdAe0n7Xj246w9C1bubpR/be4d461d5da28848420c6d9fd2b8c884/AdobeStock_1073034514.jpg)

This blog is the second in a five-part series of posts on transforming food and beverage supply chain operations with Aera, the decision intelligence agent.

The food and beverage (F&B) industry is facing a period of unprecedented evolution, shaped by evolving consumer preferences, global disruptions, and increasing sustainability demands. As consumers demand products that are personalized, eco-friendly, and transparently sourced, companies must rethink their supply chain operations. At the same time, rising costs of raw materials, labor shortages, and fluctuating demand patterns further complicate efficient management. Additionally, F&B supply chains are particularly vulnerable to waste due to the perishable nature of many products, inefficient logistics, and outdated inventory management practices. These challenges are compounded by regulatory requirements and the need to align operations with environmental goals. Companies must strike a delicate balance between maintaining profitability and meeting these multifaceted demands. Against this backdrop, reducing supply chain waste has become both a critical priority and a key differentiator for businesses seeking to thrive in a highly competitive and fast-evolving market. ### The Challenges of Managing Waste in F&B Supply Chains A major challenge for F&B companies lies in the sheer volume of supply chain waste, which is compounded by the need to balance operational efficiency with sustainability goals. The industry faces significant hurdles in managing perishable goods, which often have limited shelf lives and must be stored and transported under strict conditions to avoid spoilage. Additionally, inefficiencies in logistics, such as improper inventory allocation or delays in transportation, can lead to excessive waste and financial losses. Compounding these challenges, companies must navigate growing consumer expectations for sustainability and transparency, making it imperative to address waste issues not only as an operational concern but also as a key component of their brand reputation. These factors highlight the urgency of adopting advanced, data-driven approaches to minimize waste and improve supply chain resilience. Key challenges associated with waste include: - __Spoilage:__ Perishable goods that are not sold or redistributed in time result in direct financial losses and contribute significantly to food waste. - __Obsolescence:__ Products with shorter shelf lives often expire before reaching customers due to inefficient stock management. - __Logistics Inefficiencies:__ Poor inventory allocation and movement exacerbate waste, driving up costs and emissions. - __Sustainability Risks:__ High volumes of waste damage a companys environmental credentials and risk alienating sustainability-conscious consumers. Traditional methods for managing waste often lack the granularity, agility, and data integration necessary to track and address inefficiencies in real time. As a result, businesses miss opportunities to proactively redistribute aging inventory, optimize stock placement, or measure and mitigate waste across the supply chain. These limitations highlight the pressing need for a more advanced, data-driven approach to waste reduction. ### Aera: Revolutionizing Waste Reduction with Decision Intelligence Aera, the decision intelligence agent, empowers F&B companies to navigate these challenges with confidence. At the agents core is decision intelligence, which combines advanced analytics, artificial intelligence (AI), and automation to enable organizations to make smarter, faster, and more informed decisions. This process involves collecting and integrating data from multiple sources, analyzing it in real time, and delivering actionable insights that drive optimized outcomes. By using predictive modeling and scenario analysis, decision intelligence identifies patterns and trends that may otherwise go unnoticed, providing a clear roadmap for addressing inefficiencies and minimizing waste. This approach transforms supply chain waste reduction from a reactive effort into a proactive, strategic process. Aera provides real-time visibility, predictive insights, and automated workflows through the following skills: - __Control Tower__ provides a centralized, real-time view of inventory and waste metrics, enabling businesses to track and respond to inefficiencies as they arise. - __Sustainability Measurement__ tracks and integrates environmental performance metrics, allowing businesses to align waste reduction efforts with sustainability goals and regulatory requirements. - __Aging Inventory Management__ monitors inventory nearing expiry and redistributes products to locations or channels where they can be utilized, reducing spoilage and minimizing financial write-offs. - __Stock Rebalancing__ dynamically adjusts inventory flows to move excess stock from low-demand to high-demand areas, minimizing the risk of obsolescence and improving inventory utilization. - __Demand Forecasting__ leverages historical and external data to predict demand more accurately, ensuring inventory levels align with consumption patterns and minimizing excess. By leveraging these skills, F&B companies can achieve measurable improvements in waste mitigation: - __Reduce spoilage__ by 15-20% by identifying and addressing at-risk inventory early. - __Decrease waste-related financial losses__, improving overall profitability. - __Enhance sustainability efforts__ by minimizing food waste and environmental impact. - __Strengthen brand perception__ among consumers by aligning with sustainability goals and reducing waste footprints. Through decision intelligence, Aera enables businesses to proactively manage waste, turning it from a cost and reputational risk into an opportunity for efficiency and sustainability leadership. ### A Real-World Success Story One multinational food and beverage company recently recognized that its legacy safety stock models couldnt handle the complexities of managing perishable goods across diverse locations. Excess inventory tied up working capital while aging stock frequently led to spoilage and waste. The company deployed Aeras Dynamic Safety Stock and Inventory Balancing skills to optimize stock levels and improve inventory distribution. By dynamically redistributing aging stock and aligning inventory with real-time demand signals, the agent enabled the company to minimize spoilage and enhance operational efficiency. Advanced machine learning models provided actionable, real-time insights that significantly improved the companys efforts in waste reduction. The impact was significant, including the following outcomes: - __Up to $11M in working capital impact__ from optimized safety stock. - __$2-10M in additional revenue__ generated from improved service levels. By proactively addressing inefficiencies and waste, Aera transformed the companys approach to inventory management. With better inventory alignment and minimized spoilage, the company unlocked significant financial benefits while improving service levels across its global operations. ### The Future of Waste Reduction The success of the food and beverage industry depends on its ability to navigate supply chain complexities with agility and precision. Aera equips companies with the tools needed to turn waste reduction into a strategic advantage. By harnessing decision intelligence, F&B businesses can minimize waste, increase profitability, and deliver exceptional customer experiences while adapting to the demands of an evolving market.

As challenges persist, solutions like Aera demonstrate that with the right technology, obstacles can become opportunities. For deeper insights on transforming your supply chain, download our whitepaper, The AI Recipe for the Future of Food and Beverage Supply Chains..

title.en-US: Aera Technology Recognized in the 2025 Gartner Market Guide for ADM Platforms for Supply Chain

content.en-US:
![AdobeStock 284528861](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/2GYvqP7I93OBJb81fX7ETV/7743540ed35674f3c63420dd7af7b75f/AdobeStock_284528861.jpg)

As a leader in the growing area of decision intelligence, Aera Technology is proud to be listed in the 2025 Gartner Market Guide for Analytics and Decision-Making Platforms for Supply Chain1.

### Surging Demand for ADM Platforms The digitization of businesses today has brought new challenges and opportunities, intensifying the need for timely, accurate, and intelligent decision-making capabilities. This need is being felt across industries, but especially those that manage large and complex supply chains, resulting in a strong and rapidly growing market for advanced analytics and decision-making (ADM) platforms. Consistent with this are some key findings from the report:

Line of business teams are looking to speed up cross-functional decision making with near-real-time insights and unstructured content to quickly react to and prevent disruptions, allowing them to enhance the quality of decisions. Leaders now recognize that supply-chain-focused analytics and decision-making (ADM) platforms are enablers of flexibility and quicker time to value when dealing with a deluge of data.

### ADM Platforms Accelerate & Improve Decision Making The report mentions the growing importance of ADM platforms in enabling real-time, AI-driven decisions that improve agility, resilience, and operational efficiency. By 2027, the report asserts, 50% of business decisions will be augmented or automated by AI agents. This shift underscores the need for supply chain organizations to adopt platforms that enable rapid, informed, and scalable decision-making.

ADM platforms for supply chain management (SCM) help leaders achieve connected, contextual, continuous and compliant decisions. Leveraging composite AI the combined application (or fusion) of different AI techniques within a platform improves the platforms learning efficiency and broadens its level of knowledge representations and AI abstraction mechanisms and provides a platform to solve a wider range of supply chain problems effectively.

Aera Technology, in particular, is well positioned to lead the market in ADM platforms as the pioneer of decision intelligence (DI). Combining AI, automation, and data & analytics technologies, decision intelligence improves decision outcomes by understanding, designing and optimizing how decisions are made, resulting in more streamlined and efficient supply chain operations. The Aera Decision Cloud is designed to speed up cross-functional decision-making with near-real-time insights, enabling organizations to react to disruptions swiftly and enhance the overall quality of decisions. And with AI integrated into the platform, it improves learning efficiency and broadens the range of decision-making use cases. This innovation allows organizations to address complex supply chain challenges more effectively. ### Key Capabilities to Consider in an ADM Platform In discussing the specifics of how ADM platforms augment decision-making in typical supply chain operations, the report discusses the capabilities common across such platforms:

The main purpose of these platforms is the analysis of the data using capabilities such as modeling and optimization, which is the foundation for predictive and prescriptive analytics, among other capabilities. Hereby, different AI techniques and eventually a digital representation are leveraged to prescribe actions for manual, hybrid or automated execution. By ingesting, preparing and processing data as well as learning throughout the process such platforms also enable the coordination of decision-making processes across human decision makers and technology, fostering improvements of the decision quality across time horizons. They also allow organizations to respond more swiftly to changes and opportunities in a cross-functional environment.

By leveraging advanced AI techniques like machine learning and optimization, ADM platforms analyze data from internal and external sources in near-real-time, offering actionable insights and enhanced situational awareness. The goal is to guide users toward informed decisions by transforming data into predictive and prescriptive insights. Typically cloud-hosted and subscription-based, these platforms provide scalability, flexibility, and collaboration between human decision-makers and technology, resulting in improved decision quality and better alignment with organizational goals through actionable, data-driven insights. Similarly, the Aera Decision Cloud integrates AI, automation, and advanced analytics to transform organizational decision-making. Central to that integration of technology is Aera Agentic AI, which processes unstructured data from diverse sources, turning complex information into actionable insights and managing intricate workflows with ease. Its intuitive design enables users to create workflows and models using natural language, promoting innovation and collaboration. Agentic AI extracts data from sources like PDFs and images, integrating it into automated decision flows that deliver recommendations and execute actions, freeing up resources for higher-value tasks. As a comprehensive, composable, scalable, and trusted platform, the Aera Decision Cloud redefines how decisions are made, fostering strategic thinking, seamless collaboration, and continuous improvement all at scale, for even the largest supply chain operations. It allows organizations to build and adapt decision-making skills, harmonize data across systems into a unified decision model, and apply intelligence to evaluate scenarios, predict outcomes, and identify optimal solutions. Recommendations are then surfaced for review or applied automatically based on business rules, enabling supply chain managers to execute actions efficiently while capturing decision outputs. Over time, the platform continuously learns by recording and analyzing historical decisions and outcomes, refining future recommendations and driving deeper automation. ### An ADM Platform That Puts People First By leveraging low-code platforms, the report asserts, users in supply chain organizations can create analytical outputs without technical expertise, enabling faster, scalable decision support:

Supply chain organizations are looking to discover insights that would have otherwise gone unnoticed within existing data, and to help explore wider data sources, while minimizing human biases and accelerating time to insight. There is a strong need to make timely and informed decisions, achieving the long-desired goal of enabling decision support at scale. Thereby, organizations would not have to rely on teams of analytical developers and data scientists doing time-consuming manual coding, but would instead use a low-code approach for business analysts and business technologists to create analytical content outputs. The analytics function is hereby moved to business users without the need for them to have technical knowledge, which speeds up the process.

The Aera Decision Cloud, we believe, goes beyond enabling non-technical users with the autonomy to generate analytical output. With a people-first approach to decision intelligence, the platform empowers supply chain teams to manage the full spectrum of decisions, from fully automated and structured processes to complex, situational decisions requiring human input. This enhances both operational efficiency and team productivity, enabling management to focus on innovation, creativity, and higher-value initiatives. Customers across industries such as consumer packaged goods, high-tech, energy, pharmaceuticals, and life sciences are already achieving measurable results with the Aera Decision Cloud. By building new decision-making skills and driving continuous improvement, these organizations are unlocking even greater potential for transformative outcomes. Aera remains committed to delivering cutting-edge innovation to shape the future of decision-making in the era of autonomous business. To discover how the Aera Decision Cloud can accelerate your supply chain operations and deliver a measurable competitive advantage, request a demo today.

1Gartner, Market Guide for Analytics and Decision-Making Platforms for Supply Chain, By Christian Titze, Leonard Ammerer, David Pidsley, 14 January 2025.

title.en-US: How Decision Intelligence Drives Decision-Centric Integrated Business Planning

content.en-US:
![AdobeStock 1055916742](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/7ocuaEwVhV0SPknzMzgjVM/fc967d79c45f08dfc116acb3e8d97f60/AdobeStock_1055916742.jpeg) In todays fast-paced business environment, many Integrated Business Planning (IBP) cycles rely on processes defined 30 years ago and supported by planning concepts that are over two decades old. This traditional approach to IBP is increasingly inadequate in a world where the speed and accuracy of decision-making determine competitive advantage. ### The Limitations of Traditional IBP Traditional IBP faces significant constraints, including sequential process steps, arbitrary periodic planning and decision cycles, excessive preliminary meetings, poor integration of strategy, cumbersome data management, wasted analytics, and, most critically, an overemphasis on information rather than decision-making. Although IBP aims to support high-impact business decisions, little attention has been paid to the quality and speed of those decisions. Furthermore, IBP stakeholders often fail to effectively manage decision-making biases, document decisions, or learn from their outcomes. Addressing these gaps requires a shift toward decision-centricity, which can be achieved through decision intelligence. ### Rethinking IBP with Decision Intelligence Decision intelligence refers to the digitization, augmentation, and automation of decision-making processes. Planning decisions can be categorized into highly automated Sales and Operations Execution (S&OE), where humans play a minimal role, and augmented IBP decisions, where humans remain actively involved (in-the-loop). For example, since 2017, Aera has automated short-term S&OE decisions, and Gartner predicts that by 2026, 65% of short-term supply chain decisions will be autonomous. While IBP decisions are less frequent than S&OE decisions, they tend to recur across cycles. As illustrated by a 10-year-old schematic from a global beverage company, a projected demand-supply imbalance triggers a limited set of possible decisions to address the issue. These recurring decisions can be digitized into decision trees and augmented with cognitive tools like Aera skills. As intelligent agents, Aera skills analyze the environment, detect issues, evaluate options, and either recommend solutions or act autonomously within predefined thresholds, all while learning from their outcomes. ![blogimg1 (1)](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/YSRgF2nOHfHH9FZZyy3VM/be39d75af92f23967ffa3a749f7b39fb/blogimg1__1_.jpg)

Decision can be digitized in an IBP decision library, with decision policies & guidelines, pre-defined decision options & trade-offs and required analytics & data inputs. Digitized decisions can be automated or augmented.

The application of skills to augment IBP decisions is not confined to long-term demand and supply balancing. These skills can support decisions across every stage of the IBP cycle, including sourcing, product portfolio management, pricing, margins, promotions, gap closures, and risk and opportunity assessments. ### The Need for Decision-Centric Technology IBP managers and planners often rely on Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) and Advanced Planning and Scheduling (APS) systems, which, while useful, are not designed to focus on decision-making. ERP systems act as systems of record for enterprise data, while APS systems serve as systems of record for schedules, plans, and planning assumptions. These tools primarily facilitate inputs such as data, forecasts, and scenarios, but they fall short of focusing on the decisions themselves. In contrast, decision intelligence technology is centered on orchestrating decision-making as a measurable, data-driven business process. Aera skills, for instance, digitize IBP decisions and capture their context. This creates a system of record for decisions, documenting the decision-maker, steps taken, value generated, and overall impact. These data points can then be analyzed and monitored, enabling continuous learning and improvement. In the context of IBP, this means that all open, pending, and closed decisions can be digitized, visualized, and monitored in a control room. This provides IBP managers and senior stakeholders with a real-time view of outstanding decisions, gaps to plans, and risks and opportunities. Such decision-centric capabilities necessitate updates to traditional planning models and workflows. ### A Changing Role for the IBP Manager Decision intelligence is giving rise to new roles, such as supply chain decision intelligence managers and lead decision architects. For IBP managers, decision-centricity means shifting from discussing planning outcomes to facilitating decision streams. The focus will be on improving decision velocity, quality, and institutional learning. Using an IBP control room, managers can monitor unresolved decisions by sorting the decision log based on function, impact, urgency, or other criteria. By simply sorting the IBP decision log by function, value impact, likelihood of success, or other criticality criteria, the IBP manager can prioritize critical decisions and escalate them to leadership without waiting for the next IBP cycle, thereby accelerating decision velocity. When strategic shifts occur, digitized IBP decisions and their supporting skills may require adjustments to align with the new direction. It becomes the role of the IBP manager to facilitate updated assumptions, decision policies, decision goals, and targets across functions. Decision boundaries, as well as automation and augmentation thresholds for the skills, might need cross-functional renegotiation. After facilitating these updates, the IBP manager can maintain IBP skills in the control room to ensure decision-making stays aligned with the company strategy. ### Conclusion Despite its focus on strategic decision-making, traditional IBP has yet to embrace advanced decision-making practices. A decision-centric approach to IBP, supported by decision intelligence, is no longer optional but essential. Besides the need for decision intelligence technology, it necessitates a new mindset and approach for companies and their IBP managers. Integrating decision intelligence into IBP enables faster, higher-quality decisions with fewer meetings, reduced analytics waste, and greater employee engagement in the decision-making process. It fosters a learning organization that remains continuously aligned with company strategy. Decision-centric IBP represents not just an evolution of planning but a transformation that equips businesses to thrive in an increasingly complex and dynamic world.

title.en-US: Lowering Logistics Costs in Food & Beverage Supply Chains Using Decision Intelligence

content.en-US:
![AdobeStock 208945031](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/jHbk8IedrQSNvUbba8nr1/bc2e8f8c2eddfd6ff0c47e2d1843c397/AdobeStock_208945031.jpg)

This blog is the third in a five-part series of posts on transforming food and beverage supply chain operations with Aera, the decision intelligence agent.

The food and beverage (F&B) industry is undergoing a seismic shift as it grapples with challenges on multiple fronts. From evolving consumer expectations for personalization, transparency, and sustainability to rising operational costs, the complexities of supply chain management have never been greater. These dynamics are compounded by the volatility of global markets, labor shortages, and unpredictable disruptions in logistics. To stay competitive, food and beverage companies must rethink how they approach supply chain management, particularly in the realm of logistics. Many organizations struggle to maintain a balance between reducing costs, meeting service demands, and adhering to environmental commitments. This makes innovation and smarter decision-making critical for survival. ### The Logistics Cost Challenges of F&B Supply Chains Managing logistics in the food and beverage sector has become increasingly challenging. Companies are under pressure to address the growing costs of energy, transportation, and labor, while maintaining affordability for increasingly price-sensitive consumers. Efficient logistics management is no longer just an operational necessity it is a critical driver of profitability and customer satisfaction. Yet lowering the cost of logistics presents a unique set of hurdles. Fluctuating fuel prices, increased regulatory compliance for sustainability, and difficulties in securing reliable transportation partners have all added layers of complexity to logistics operations. Additionally, companies must contend with shrinking delivery windows driven by rising consumer expectations for speed and convenience. These factors create a delicate balancing act: companies must reduce expenses without compromising service quality, environmental sustainability, or supply chain resilience. F&B companies encounter a range of systemic challenges that hinder their ability to achieve logistics efficiency: - __Data Silos.__ Critical logistics and transportation data often exist in disconnected systems, making it difficult to access and utilize effectively. - __Lack of Integration.__ Limited connectivity between logistics providers prevents companies from achieving real-time visibility into inventory levels and transportation risks. - __Sustainability Tracking Challenges.__ Measuring and reducing carbon emissions tied to logistics remains a complex and under-addressed issue. Traditional tools and manual processes often fail to address these challenges, leaving companies unable to integrate diverse data streams or anticipate inefficiencies. The result is higher operational costs, increased emissions, and suboptimal service levels that fail to meet consumer and regulatory expectations. These challenges underscore the need for a more sophisticated, data-driven approach to lowering the cost of logistics. ### Aera: Optimizing Logistics Spend with Decision Intelligence Aera, the decision intelligence agent, provides a transformative solution for F&B companies seeking to optimize logistics operations. By leveraging advanced analytics, automation, and real-time decision intelligence, the agent enables companies to tackle logistics challenges head-on. The platform offers a suite of skills designed to drive efficiency and sustainability, including: - __CO2 Emissions Management__ tracks and analyzes transportation-related carbon emissions, offering actionable insights to reduce environmental impact without compromising cost efficiency. - __Efficient Shipping and Stockout Prevention__ dynamically plans and adjusts shipment schedules and routes to maximize truck utilization, eliminate unnecessary shipments, and ensure timely product availability. - __Logistics Event Management__ monitors logistics operations in real time, flagging potential delays or disruptions and providing actionable recommendations to mitigate risks of stockouts or delivery failures. By adopting these skills, food and beverage companies can achieve measurable improvements in logistics performance: - __Lower costs__ of fuel and labor by 5-15% by optimizing transportation schedules and improving truck utilization. - __Enhanced sustainability__ by reducing transportation emissions and waste through better logistics planning. - __Improved visibility__ through real-time insights into logistics operations, enabling faster, more data-driven decisions. With Aera, logistics management becomes a more cost-effective, sustainable, and agile process. It empowers companies to align operational efficiency with the increasing consumer and regulatory demands for transparency and environmental responsibility. ### A Real-World Success Story The transformative power of Aera is best illustrated through real-world examples. Consider the case of a leading confectionery company that faced significant logistics inefficiencies, including poor truck utilization, delayed stock movements, and manual trans-shipping processes. These issues not only drove up costs but also limited visibility into stock levels, resulting in suboptimal inventory placement across warehouses. The company turned to Aera, leveraging the platforms Stock Rebalancing and Logistics Optimization Skills to streamline its operations. The agent automated stock transfer orders and optimized truckloads, dynamically adjusting shipments based on real-time signals. This approach delivered dramatic results: - __$14M in losses prevented__ by identifying expiring products early. - __$5M in logistics cost savings__ through improved planning. - __87-95% truck utilization__ achieved. - __6,000 fewer trucks__ on the road annually, reducing environmental impact. - __80% reduction in planner workload__, saving $680K in logistics labor costs. By replacing reactive processes with automated, data-driven decisions, the company significantly improved both cost efficiency and sustainability. Optimized truck utilization not only reduced transportation expenses but also minimized carbon emissions. Meanwhile, automating stock transfers allowed planners to focus on strategic, high-value tasks. Aeras integration of sustainability considerations into logistics operations demonstrated its ability to balance cost savings with environmental goals. ### The Future of Inventory Management As the food and beverage industry continues to evolve, its success will depend on the ability to navigate increasingly complex supply chains with agility and precision. Aera provides companies with the tools they need to meet these challenges head-on. By harnessing the power of decision intelligence, F&B businesses can streamline their logistics to reduce spend and deliver exceptional customer experiences all while aligning with the growing demand for sustainability. The challenges of todays logistics landscape are formidable, but solutions like Aera prove that innovation can turn obstacles into opportunities. For companies seeking to transform their supply chains, decision intelligence is no longer a luxury its a necessity.

To learn more about how Aera can help your business thrive, download our whitepaper, The AI Recipe for the Future of Food and Beverage Supply Chains.

title.en-US: Increasing Service Levels in Food & Beverage Supply Chains Using Decision Intelligence

content.en-US:
![AdobeStock 792976172](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/qWQ3x8LpEryCUgWlkdfjP/1785e02d7fff43e54ceb60fdd76417d0/AdobeStock_792976172.jpg)

This blog is the fourth in a five-part series of posts on transforming food and beverage supply chain operations with Aera, the decision intelligence agent.

The food and beverage (F&B) industry is experiencing a profound transformation as it navigates an intricate landscape of evolving consumer expectations, regulatory pressures, and operational challenges. Consumers now demand greater transparency and sustainability, while businesses contend with rising costs, global market volatility, and unpredictable disruptions in logistics. Conventional supply chain management approaches are proving inadequate in this dynamic environment, necessitating a shift toward data-driven, agile decision-making. To maintain a competitive edge, F&B companies must harmonize demand with inventory management while ensuring customer satisfaction without excessive stock levels. Achieving this balance remains a formidable challenge, as organizations strive to reduce costs, enhance service levels, and uphold sustainability commitments. The key to success lies in innovation and the adoption of smarter decision-making frameworks. ### The Service Challenges of F&B Supply Chains The unique characteristics of F&B supply chains introduce a range of service-related challenges. The perishable nature of food products, stringent regulatory requirements, and rising customer expectations necessitate precise and efficient operations. Below are some of the primary obstacles that businesses in this industry face: - __Supply Chain Disruptions.__ Ingredient shortages caused by climate conditions, geopolitical issues, or supplier failures can often lead to production delays and stock shortages. In addition, transportation issues, such as shipping delays, port congestion, and trucking shortages, can further impact delivery timelines and result in customer dissatisfaction. - __Product Quality and Safety.__ Since food products are perishable, companies must carefully monitor cold chain logistics to ensure temperature control and freshness. Any failure in this area can lead to spoilage and customer complaints. Additionally, regulatory compliance is a constant challenge, as food safety laws require strict adherence, and any missteps such as contamination or mislabeling can lead to recalls that damage a companys reputation. - __Order Fulfillment Challenges__ arise due to inconsistent inventory levels and last-mile delivery issues. Demand fluctuations and supplier inconsistencies can cause stockouts or overstocking, making it difficult to meet customer expectations. Ensuring timely delivery, especially in direct-to-consumer models, is crucial, as delays can result in spoiled goods and dissatisfied customers. - __Customer Communication & Transparency.__ The lack of real-time tracking and communication can pose a significant issue. Customers expect transparency and frequent updates on order status, but many companies struggle with visibility across their supply chains. When issues arise, handling customer complaints effectively and providing swift resolutions are essential to maintaining trust and loyalty. - __Sustainability & Ethical Sourcing__ present additional challenges, as consumers increasingly demand transparency regarding how ingredients are sourced and how companies minimize their environmental impact. Ensuring that all suppliers meet ethical and sustainability standards is complex, and any failure in this regard can result in customer backlash. - __Technology & Data Management__ can hinder supply chain efficiency. Many companies still rely on outdated systems that make it difficult to track inventory, predict demand, and ensure smooth operations. Cybersecurity risks are also a concern, as data breaches affecting supply chain management systems can disrupt operations and erode customer trust. To address these challenges, companies must invest in supply chain technology, such as AI-driven demand forecasting, IoT tracking for real-time monitoring, and blockchain for transparency. Strengthening supplier relationships and diversifying sourcing can help reduce dependency on a single source. Improving cold chain logistics through advanced refrigeration technologies and real-time temperature monitoring is essential for product quality. Additionally, enhancing customer communication with proactive updates and a robust support system can improve satisfaction. Lastly, committing to sustainability by partnering with certified ethical suppliers and reducing waste through efficient logistics can help businesses meet consumer expectations while strengthening their brand reputation. ### Aera: Maximizing Service Levels with Decision Intelligence Aera, the decision intelligence agent, is redefining how F&B companies elevate supply chain service levels. Powered by advanced analytics, automation, and real-time decision intelligence, it enables businesses to consistently meet customer expectations while optimizing inventory performance. Its impact comes to life through the following skills: - __Demand Forecasting__ provides detailed predictions of future demand based on historical and external data, ensuring inventory levels align with anticipated customer needs. - __Demand Sensing__ analyzes real-time signals, such as market trends and weather data, to adjust forecasts dynamically and respond to demand shifts. - __Stockout Prediction and Prevention__ identifies potential stockout risks in advance and recommends actions to mitigate them, ensuring uninterrupted product availability. - __Dynamic Safety Stock Adjustments__ continuously recalibrate safety stock levels to balance service levels with inventory costs, adapting to changing market and supply chain conditions. - __Control Tower__ centralizes real-time visibility into inventory and supply chain operations, enabling businesses to proactively address disruptions and maintain service reliability. By implementing these skills, F&B companies can achieve significant improvements in key performance areas: - __Maximized Revenue:__ Ensuring product availability leads to a 10-20% increase in sales opportunities. - __Reduced Costs:__ Optimized inventory management reduces unnecessary stockholding, cutting costs by 5-10%. - __Enhanced Customer Satisfaction:__ Reliable service delivery strengthens brand loyalty and customer retention. - __Operational Agility:__ Improved decision-making enables businesses to navigate supply chain complexities with precision. Through decision intelligence, Aera transforms inventory and service level management, equipping businesses with the agility and insights needed to thrive in a complex and rapidly changing marketplace. ### A Real-World Success Story The impact of Aera is exemplified by a global consumer packaged goods (CPG) company that struggled with inventory shortages and inefficient manual planning. Despite access to estimated time of arrival (ETA) data, the company lacked an automated system to integrate it into supply projections. As a result, logistics delays led to frequent stockouts and missed sales opportunities. By deploying Aeras __Stockout Prediction and Prevention__ skill, the company automated shortage identification and resolution. The system harmonized ETA data with inventory insights, enabling proactive measures such as stock transfers and production adjustments. This resulted in remarkable improvements: - __100% accuracy__ in shortage identification and impact assessment - __20-40% reduction in manual planning efforts__ - __Enhanced responsiveness__, reducing disruptions, increasing service levels, and driving revenue growth This success story exemplifies how decision intelligence can revolutionize supply chain management. By integrating real-time insights and automation, the company significantly enhanced service levels, reduced operational inefficiencies, and improved overall customer satisfaction. The adoption of Aera underscores the transformative potential of AI-driven solutions in addressing complex supply chain challenges and driving business growth. ### Transforming Supply Chain Service Performance for Tomorrow As supply chain complexities continue to escalate, agility and precision in inventory management will determine the success of F&B businesses. Aera equips companies with the necessary tools to navigate challenges efficiently, ensuring optimal product availability, cost efficiency, and exceptional customer experiences. Furthermore, decision intelligence enables businesses to align with sustainability goals while optimizing operational performance. The future of F&B supply chains lies in intelligent automation and data-driven decision-making. Companies that embrace these innovations will not only overcome current challenges but also secure long-term competitive advantages. Solutions like Aera demonstrate that decision intelligence is no longer optional it is imperative for sustained growth and resilience in a rapidly evolving marketplace.

To explore how Aera can transform your supply chain operations, download our whitepaper:
The AI Recipe for the Future of Food and Beverage Supply Chains.

title.en-US: Navigating Tariff Volatility with Decision Intelligence: A Strategic Framework

content.en-US:
![AdobeStock 217779667](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/1TttPCM5aYoX0Nsm2CYrqK/3443a8be3d12420bd484362d2d6328da/AdobeStock_217779667.jpg) Aggressive tariffs designed to reshore U.S. manufacturing have become a major concern for C-suite executives in 2025. These rapidly evolving policies are not mere regulatory challenges they represent a fundamental shift in global trade dynamics, demanding an immediate and strategic response from businesses with cross-border operations. These new financial measures intensify the difficulties in an already challenging landscape struggling through supply chain disruptions and increasing competition. Now, without a sophisticated, proactive tariff strategy that integrates harmoniously into existing operations and tech stacks, organizations risk shrinking profits, weakened supply chain performance, and declining customer satisfaction and market share. The decision intelligence at the core of Aera Decision Cloud offers a powerful solution to these challenges. ### Decision Intelligence Use Cases for Tariff Management Given the volatility and urgency of this topic, lets dive into the key use cases where tariff-driven supply chain disruptions create significant challenges for businesses worldwide. Decision intelligence (DI) can significantly enhance a companys ability to navigate such disruptions. By leveraging DI, companies can create adaptive systems that improve decision-making in real time, leading to more effective responses and strategies. #### Use Case 1: Predictive Risk Assessment and Scenario Modeling One of the key capabilities of decision intelligence is predictive analytics. By integrating real-time data from trade regulations, historical patterns, and market conditions, DI systems can forecast the likelihood of new tariffs and their potential effects on different parts of the supply chain. This helps businesses prepare for disruptions before they occur, enabling proactive measures such as adjusting sourcing strategies, optimizing inventory, or diversifying suppliers. For example, a DI system could predict how a proposed tariff would affect the cost of raw materials from a specific region and provide alternative supplier recommendations or pricing strategies. #### Use Case 2: Dynamic Sourcing and Supplier Optimization When tariffs cause supply chain disruptions, companies often need to find new sources of goods to maintain operations. Decision intelligence systems use advanced optimization algorithms to assess and recommend the best suppliers based on factors such as cost, quality, reliability, and proximity to avoid additional tariffs or delays. These systems continuously evaluate multiple factors, such as potential changes in tariffs or international trade agreements, to recommend the best alternative suppliers or markets, in real time, allowing companies to mitigate the impact of tariffs and maintain an advantage over competitors. For instance, if a new tariff is placed on Chinese steel imports, a DI system could recommend shifting sourcing to other countries with lower tariffs or exploring domestic production options. #### Use Case 3: Inventory Management and Optimization Tariff-induced supply disruptions often lead to inventory shortages or excesses. DI systems help manage inventory by using algorithms that assess demand forecasts, supply constraints, and tariff impacts on production timelines. By dynamically adjusting inventory levels and replenishment cycles based on real-time data, DI can ensure that companies dont face stockouts or overstocking, which reduces their costs while maintaining the satisfaction of their customers. For example, a company can use DI to proactively adjust inventory levels of raw materials and finished goods when anticipating tariff-related supply disruptions. This helps prevent production delays and ensures a steady flow of critical components. #### Use Case 4: Price and Cost Optimization Tariffs often lead to higher costs for businesses that rely on imported goods. Decision intelligence can help companies determine the optimal pricing strategies to absorb increased costs while remaining competitive. By analyzing price elasticity, customer preferences, and competitive pricing strategies, DI systems can dynamically suggest price adjustments that maintain profitability and market share. Additionally, they can recommend internal cost-cutting measures or help identify areas where operational efficiencies can be achieved. For instance, a DI system could automatically recommend price increases in markets where customers are less sensitive to price changes or suggest product modifications to offset tariff costs. #### Use Case 5: Regulatory and Compliance Monitoring Governments frequently update trade regulations and tariffs, making it difficult for businesses to stay compliant. Decision intelligence systems can be designed to continuously monitor regulatory changes and tariffs across different regions, ensuring that businesses remain compliant without having to manually track the updates. By analyzing these changes and correlating them with supply chain risks, DI systems can recommend actions, such as adjusting the product portfolio or shifting production locations to mitigate the impact of tariffs. For example, if a government changes tariffs on imports from certain countries, the DI system would alert relevant teams and propose a compliance strategy to avoid penalties or trade restrictions. ### Why Compliance Alone Isnt Enough The rapid onslaught of new trade policies is further complicating an already strained operating environment. Previously, planning teams were tasked with managing increasing supply chain disruptions and making a growing number of unmade decisions. Today they must now contend with additional layers of complexity based on the introduction of transnational tariffs that can change on a dime, significantly increasing organizational pressure and, more importantly, escalating risks when changes arent addressed in real time. Before we delve deeper into why decision intelligence is the optimal solution for navigating tariff volatility and enhancing overall supply chain performance, it's crucial to address a common misconception: that decision intelligence is a cutting-edge technology reserved solely for mature organizations with perfectly honed data management strategies. This simply isnt the case. Aera Technology is equipped to partner with companies across the maturity spectrum. The most important takeaway here is that getting started is paramount, and we are committed to guiding you toward success on your decision intelligence journey. In fact, regardless of where your organization stands in terms of data maturity, recognizing the importance of adopting AI technologies to ingest, harmonize, and analyze data is the critical first step. By taking the leap to embrace solutions that can mitigate the impact of tariffs, you immediately elevate the urgency and necessity of adopting technologies that can keep pace with today's rapidly evolving and complex business landscape. Whether your data is perfectly structured or still a work in progress, starting your decision intelligence journey now will position you to better manage and optimize your supply chain amidst ongoing disruptions. As Gartner has noted, "Executive leaders who anticipate that current tariff volatility will persist for years, rather than months, must understand that businesses cannot emerge successfully by staying the same as they are today. The winners will reinvent or reinvigorate their business strategy, developing new capabilities that drive competitive advantage. This observation rings particularly true as 60% of companies are already overhauling their supply chains in response to tariff uncertainty and market volatility. The message is clear: adaptation isn't just beneficial it's essential for survival. ### Why Traditional Solutions Fall Short

In a previous blog, Why Decision Intelligence is the Last Mile in Enterprise Software, we examined why existing technologies aren't equipped to effectively tackle the complexities of todays business landscape. With this new wrinkle, that analysis resonates more than ever. Traditional supply chain planning systems, while valuable, struggle to meet today's dynamic challenges. Their static planning cycles can't keep pace with rapid changes, and their scenario modeling capabilities remain limited. These systems typically operate reactively rather than predictively, hampered by siloed data architectures that prevent comprehensive analysis of complex tariff implications.

Similarly, conventional business intelligence (BI) tools show significant limitations in addressing today's tariff challenges. Their focus on historical data rather than predictive insights leaves organizations vulnerable to emerging risks. The insufficient real-time capabilities and heavy reliance on manual intervention make it nearly impossible to respond swiftly to tariff changes. Without automated decision-making features, companies struggle to scale their response to rapidly evolving trade policies. In short, companies committed to maintaining their competitive edge must embrace a new way of thinking. ### Decision Intelligence: Transforming Tariff Management in Global Trade and More As we've discussed, the world has fundamentally changed, and complexity, volatility, and uncertainty are unlikely to diminish anytime soon. Preparing for the future is the only way forward. Decision intelligence has emerged as the most powerful and transformative solution to combat the new normal, combining advanced analytics, artificial intelligence, and predictive modeling to revolutionize how businesses navigate a VUCA world one marked by volatility, uncertainty, complexity, and ambiguity. Decision intelligence represents a breakthrough technology that transforms how organizations handle both tariff management and supply chain optimization. Aera Decision Cloud, with DI at its core, is a comprehensive platform that combines advanced data analytics with predictive modeling to generate AI-driven insights, converting disparate and complex data streams into actionable intelligence. What sets DI apart from traditional analytics technologies is its ability to go beyond historical data analysis it not only anticipates future scenarios and recommends optimal strategies but also executes these decisions across integrated systems. This end-to-end automation delivers unprecedented consistency and visibility across global operations, enabling organizations to achieve a level of unified decision-making that was previously impossible. Specifically for tariff management, decision intelligence excels at both anticipating potential supply chain challenges and revealing hidden opportunities. By continuously analyzing global trade data, DI empowers teams to pinpoint vulnerable products and components and discover optimal, often overlooked, strategies to meet customer demand. This proactive approach enables organizations to optimize their supply chains by evaluating alternative sourcing options and suppliers before tariff changes impact their bottom line. ### Building Future-Proof Organizations The true value of decision intelligence lies not only in future-proofing organizations against trade volatility, but also in its capacity to digitize decision-making across the enterprise through readily available and custom-built capabilities. Aera Decision Cloud is an agent-based SaaS platform that delivers unmatched agility, enabling organizations to maximize existing resources while fostering cross-functional capabilities that adapt to evolving needs. The system provides enhanced visibility into extended supplier networks, enabling organizations to identify and mitigate risks before they impact operations. This comprehensive view, combined with AI-driven continuous improvement, ensures that organizations stay ahead of market changes rather than reacting to them. ### The Path Forward As global trade complexity continues to increase, decision intelligence becomes not just an advantage but a necessity. Organizations that embrace DI position themselves to: - Transform tariff management from a reactive process to a strategic advantage - Build resilient supply chains that adapt automatically to change - Optimize costs while maintaining competitive positioning - Ensure regulatory compliance without increasing overhead - Develop sustainable, scalable operations that grow with their business The future of global trade belongs to organizations that can navigate complexity with intelligence and agility across multiple business functions. Decision intelligence provides the tools and capabilities to make this future a reality today.

To learn more about Aera Technologys approach to mitigating tariff impacts, request a demo of our solution today.

Industry-Specific Impacts of Tariffs

Consumer Packaged Goods (CPG)

  • While many CPG products are assembled in the U.S., they rely heavily on imported raw materials such as cocoa, spices, coffee, and other ingredients subject to tariffs.
  • Packaging costs will be impacted 25% on steel and 10% on aluminum.

Pharmaceuticals

  • A 10% increase in pharmaceutical costs is expected due to tariffs.
  • Approximately 80% of active pharmaceutical ingredients (APIs) used in U.S. drugs are sourced overseas, with China being a major supplier. Tariffs on these imports will significantly raise production costs and exacerbate drug shortages.

Medical Devices

  • The U.S. heavily relies on imports for medical equipment and supplies, particularly from China.
  • In 2024 alone (as of May 2), the U.S. imported $14.9 billion in medical equipment, compared to $14 billion during the same period in 2023 (Census Bureau).
  • About 69% of U.S.-marketed medical devices are manufactured entirely outside the U.S., making them highly vulnerable to tariff increases.

Automotive

  • Tariffs have led to a 1520% increase in steel costs, directly impacting automotive manufacturing.
  • Automotive components often cross borders multiple times before final assembly, compounding the cost implications of tariffs at each stage. This significantly affects profitability and pricing strategies.

High Tech Hardware Manufacturing

  • A 10% increase in the cost of goods sold (COGS) due to tariffs could nearly eliminate operating income for PC and server vendors, whose typical operating margins are only 510%.
  • Sales of laptops and tablets could decline by up to 68%, while smartphone purchases could drop by 37%, severely impacting high-tech manufacturers.

Energy

  • Rising energy costs due to tariffs will increase overhead for manufacturers, further squeezing profit margins.
  • Companies may struggle to offset these additional costs while maintaining competitive pricing.
