content.en-US:
![Spring release landing page and blog recap cover](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/2NhqSB093I5W8dS1ulxPAo/3090a92120352bbceedcbc36ff6e52ed/Spring_release_landing_page_and_blog_recap_cover.jpg) ### Summary The Spring 25 Release marks a significant step forward for Aera, the decision intelligence agent, broadening both its functional reach and its ease of use. Building on feedback from live deployments, the release targets three strategic pillars: transforming the decision experience, accelerating adoption, and enabling confident roll-outs. By combining richer decision analytics with low-code configuration and stronger governance, Spring 25 shortens the path from idea to measurable impact. Aera Calc now gives planners a familiar, Excel-like workspace that connects directly to live enterprise data. Enhanced Chat capabilities surface answers through natural language while coordinating multiple cooperating agents behind the scenes. A forthcoming Data Wizard simplifies onboarding new data sources, and a revamped user interface complete with certified pages and color-coding makes it easier for every persona to see, trust, and act on AI-generated insights. Together, these advances position organizations to scale decision intelligence faster and with greater confidence. ### Key Takeaways
  1. Scenario planning with Aera Calc
    Aera Calc brings spreadsheet flexibility to decision intelligence. Users can write formulas, build what-if scenarios, and immediately view the impact on KPIs such as service level, margin, or inventory all without writing code or waiting for overnight batch jobs. This live, cell-based modeling helps cross-functional teams iterate rapidly and converge on the best course of action.
  2. Smarter, multi-agent Chat
    The updated Chat interface now interprets context and user intent more deeply. It can launch workflows that span several agents one to pull demand signals, another to reconcile supply, and a third to suggest mitigation steps then return a consolidated answer with an auto-generated dashboard. Inline explanations show the data and logic used, fostering transparency and user trust.
  3. Self-service Data Wizard (coming soon)
    Connecting new data sets no longer requires a lengthy IT ticket. The three-step wizard walks users through source selection, field mapping, and data validation, automatically creating the pipelines needed to feed Calc, Chat, and other skills accelerating time-to-value for new use cases.
  4. Governance through Streams & Deployment Manager
    Streams record every model edit, data change, and deployment action, providing an immutable audit trail. Deployment Manager packages agents, dashboards, and configurations into version-controlled bundles that can be promoted across environments with a single click reducing compliance risk and speeding up the release cycle.
  5. Enhanced Discovery & Workspaces UX
    A refreshed interface introduces certified pages, richer table components, and customizable color palettes for faster insight recognition. A new Deployment Manager role grants targeted privileges, ensuring the right users can move content through the lifecycle without over-permissive access. Collectively, these updates improve usability, governance, and adoption across business and technical teams.
  6. Ability to to build and embed LLM-powered agents
    The Spring 25 Release introduces a foundational advancement in agentic AI: the ability to create decision intelligence agents that leverage large language models to solve complex business problems. These agents can operate on their own or be embedded into Skills and integrated with Process Builder, allowing them to participate in broader decision workflows. Under the hood, Chat already uses multiple cooperating LLM agents to interpret questions, identify relevant data sources, and generate Discovery objects. Now, with this release, users can build similar agents to address domain-specific decision scenarios bringing natural language reasoning into the core of the platform and expanding the reach of agentic AI across the enterprise.
  7. Roadmap aligned to three pillars
    Every Spring 25 Release feature ladders up to transforming decision experiences, accelerating broad adoption, or enabling confident roll-outs. This clear alignment helps customers map incremental improvements like faster scenario building or tighter governance to long-term transformation goals and ROI.
### Speakers
Lalitha Sundaramurthy, SVP Product, Aera Technology
Guides the product vision and roadmap, bringing two decades of data and analytics leadership.
Mustafa Kabul, SVP Data Science, Aera Technology
Leads optimization, machine-learning, and generative-AI advances that power Aeras agentic intelligence.
Joe Dery, VP Customer Success, Aera Technology
Partners with clients to translate new platform capabilities into measurable business value.
### Full Recording

Access the full webinar recording here.

### Q&A

Q: The formula example you showed is it exactly like Excel? Or a little different? What can users expect?
A: The formulas in Calc are indeed similar to Excel, but theyre not exactly the same. We've fine-tuned the experience to go beyond what traditional spreadsheets offer. With Calc, users can access data across multiple dimensions, tapping into the power of the Decision Data Model (DDM). For example, you can reference a specific member of a dimension or perform a parent lookup capabilities that go beyond standard Excel functionality. While the syntax is familiar and Excel-like, Calc is much more advanced, enabling users to write formulas that reflect the real-world complexities of enterprise decision-making.

Q: Where does Calc fit into the product vision and strategy? Was the motivation behind the feature to support existing workflows, offer a standalone tool or both?
A: Its very much both. Calc was designed to work in two modes: as a standalone modeling and scenario tool, and as a seamlessly embedded component within Skills. In standalone mode, users can create models and run scenarios directly helping them make decisions in the moment as new, unexpected events arise. Think about a delayed truck or a product that suddenly needs to be introduced without prior planning. These arent part of your standard workflows, but they still require immediate decisions. Calc enables users to simulate outcomes in these situations quickly and make informed decisions day to day.
At the same time, Calc can be integrated into Skills to power recommendations and automate decision logic. By using Calcs Excel-like formula language, you can easily capture and reuse logic that drives automation. This dramatically simplifies and accelerates Skill development.
Looking ahead, Calc plays a central role in our broader product vision. We plan to integrate it directly with agentic, so that as agents operate and reason through the instructions users provide, theyll have Calc in their toolset. Agents will be able to run different scenarios, evaluate the outcomes, and make decisions automatically all in line with enterprise objectives. So, to sum up, Calc enhances existing workflows, empowers standalone scenario modeling, and brings new capabilities to agentic decision-making. Its a key contributor to the power and flexibility of the overall Aera platform.

Q: Can Aera Chat generate insights using multiple data sources? For instance, could it answer something like, What is the average inventory cost and level in my local warehouses that fulfill Category A customers? And can it handle more logic-driven questions like, Which inventory targets should I change to lower overall costs?
A: Yes, Aera Chat is fully capable of handling those types of complex queries by tapping into multiple data sources. It does this by building Discovery visualizations that aggregate and display the data in a way that supports deeper insight. Behind the scenes, it uses Data Views to source the data and relies on the descriptions embedded in those Data Views to understand the context and structure of the underlying data.
However, it does depend on the data thats available in the Decision Data Model (DDM). For example, if you already have a Skill designed to optimize inventory decisions, that Skill likely involves advanced mathematical optimization techniques to generate its recommendations. Once those recommendations are available in the platform, they can be exposed to Aera Chat. That means Chat can retrieve the results from those optimization processes and deliver an answer thats accurate, actionable, and context-aware even for questions that combine logic, scenario analysis, and multiple data sets.

Q: What does the Data View need to look like in order for Chat to generate visuals and responses from a simple query?
A: For Aera Chat to generate effective visuals and responses, each Data View needs to be properly described. At the Data View level, you should include a description that clearly explains the overall purpose of that Data View. In addition to this high-level description, each individual measure and dimension should also have a short description that explains what it represents. These descriptions dont need to be lengthy or complex just enough to make their meaning clear.
You can add these descriptions directly at the Data View level, or to the underlying Subject Area and Dimension objects. With this descriptive metadata in place, Chat can better understand the structure and intent of the data. This enables it to interpret user questions accurately and craft responses including Discovery visuals that align with the users goals.

Q: I saw OpenAI listed in the LLM options. How does Aera treat and protect confidential customer information when using LLMs?
A: While we didnt demonstrate this during the session due to time constraints, it's important to know that LLM management is handled at the account level by Aera admins. This means each client has the ability to control which LLM is used. You are not required to use OpenAI it's simply one available option. Clients can connect their own LLMs to Aera and use them to create and power their own agents. This ensures that all data handling aligns with each clients specific data privacy and security policies. In short, model choice and data control are fully in the hands of the customer.

Q: With all these new features, how much is a developer still needed? Or are these tools mostly geared toward data scientists and end users?
A: These capabilities particularly Aera Chat are built with end users in mind. As long as the relevant data is available in the platform, users can begin interacting with it directly. Theres no need for developer involvement to ask questions, run scenarios, or explore insights. This design empowers business users to make decisions faster, without relying on technical support for everyday analysis.

Q: I didnt hear Lalitha mention joining data from multiple subject areas into a single Data View. Is that capability available in this release or is it planned for later?
A: That functionality joining data from multiple Subject Areas into one Data View is targeted for release in Q3 of this year.

Q: Can you share a fictitious business example of what agentic AI makes possible?
A: While its a great question, many of these use cases are already very real. One strong example is claims management. Aeras agentic AI is already being used to help read and process claims that arrive in multiple document formats. Using a combination of Aeras automation capabilities and large language model reasoning, these agents are able to classify and process claims at both scale and speed. If youd like to dive deeper into this use case, theres a dedicated webinar available on demand that explores it in detail.

Q: Are there any plans to make debugging easier? Sometimes the runtime logs dont show enough detail to identify which process node is causing the issue.
A: Yes the Profiler tool is designed to address exactly that. You can use Profiler to pinpoint which specific node in a process is causing an issue. It provides deeper visibility into process execution and helps eliminate the guesswork often associated with runtime logs.

Q: Have any Deployment Manager issues been addressed? Specifically, problems like execution plans referencing objects not yet existing in the target environment, or the inability to retrieve the object ID of stream steps?
A: Weve been actively working to resolve critical issues with Deployment Manager. That said, it would be helpful to clarify which specific problems youre referring to if you can share more detail, well be able to provide a more targeted update.

Q: What are the downstream applications of a Calc model? Can it be exposed in the UI so users can take actions after scenario analysis?
A: Yes. Calc models are fully usable as standalone interfaces, where users can interact with them directly. They can also be embedded within either new or existing Skills. In that context, users can engage in scenario analysis through the Calc model and then act on the recommendations that result all within the same workflow. This flexibility allows organizations to integrate scenario-based planning more deeply into their decision processes.

Q: Its great to see how easy it is to set up Aera Calc. I see a lot of potential to replace our existing custom UIs. Since its in beta, when can implementation partners begin testing, and when will clients be able to start using it?
A: Were targeting August 1 for deployment of the Spring Release to partner environments. Formal enablement will be available just a few days later, on August 7. Thats when implementation partners can begin hands-on testing, and clients can begin planning their own rollouts.

title.en-US: Reducing Waste and Meeting ESG Targets in High-Tech Supply Chains Using Decision Intelligence

content.en-US:
![Blog Hero Banner - Reducing Waste in High-Tech Supply Chains (1)](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/4K7Unn2MiAoI1y59YMumkf/ba6fd56e5287556ae4918791830cae47/Blog_Hero_Banner_-_Reducing_Waste_in_High-Tech_Supply_Chains__1_.jpg)

This is the third in a five-part series of blog posts on transforming high-tech supply chain operations with Aera, the decision intelligence agent.

### A Complex Network Grappling with Waste and Accountability In todays high-tech supply chains, sustainability isnt just a corporate goal its a business imperative. As companies face increasing pressure to reduce waste, lower emissions, and meet ambitious ESG targets, the complexity of doing so has never been greater. Shorter product lifecycles, intricate global networks, and unpredictable demand patterns make it difficult to optimize resources without generating excess. From obsolete components to redundant logistics, waste accumulates in ways that are hard to track and even harder to eliminate, especially when traditional tools cant keep up. To build more sustainable operations, high-tech manufacturers need more than isolated green initiatives. They need a smarter way to align operational decisions with environmental and financial outcomes in real time, at scale. Thats where decision intelligence comes in. ### The Sustainability Challenge in High-Tech Supply Chains For high-tech manufacturers, sustainability has become a high-stakes balancing act. On one side are growing ESG commitments, tightening regulations, and rising expectations from investors and customers alike. On the other are operational pressures to control costs, maintain service levels, and keep production moving in a volatile global landscape. At the heart of this challenge lies the issue of waste. Whether its aging components, surplus inventory, inefficient logistics, or excess packaging, waste shows up in ways that are often difficult to see and even harder to reduce. Most high-tech products involve thousands of parts sourced globally, with complex supply routes and frequent design changes. In this context, even small misalignments can compound quickly into environmental and financial liabilities. Several systemic challenges stand in the way: - __Excess inventory contributes to unnecessary waste, scrap, and carbon emissions__, especially when obsolete materials are written off or scrapped without efforts to recover value. - __ESG mandates enhanced traceability, transparency, and accurate reporting__ across the supply chain, from sourcing and manufacturing to distribution and end-of-life. - __Sustainability goals often seem at odds with cost containment efforts__, making it difficult to justify proactive interventions when ROI is unclear. - __Reactive waste handling drives up both environmental and financial impact__, as organizations scramble to dispose of surplus stock after it has already lost value. - __Scope 3 emissions remain particularly difficult to measure, monitor, and mitigate__, especially in globally distributed, multi-tier supplier networks. Traditional waste management efforts often reliant on static spreadsheets, disjointed systems, and lagging indicators are no longer sufficient. These approaches rarely provide the real-time insight or cross-functional coordination needed to prevent waste before it happens. As a result, opportunities to repurpose inventory, rebalance supply, or align emissions data with operational decisions are routinely missed. In a landscape where ESG compliance is becoming more closely tied to long-term competitiveness, high-tech companies need a smarter, more connected approach one that embeds sustainability into day-to-day decision-making and transforms waste reduction from a one-time initiative into an ongoing advantage. ### How the Industry Is Responding: From After-the-Fact Accounting to Proactive Waste Prevention To meet escalating ESG demands without sacrificing operational performance, many high-tech companies are rethinking how they manage waste. The shift is moving away from traditional approaches that rely on delayed reporting and manual cleanup, toward proactive systems that use real-time data, AI, and automation to reduce environmental impact at the source. This transformation reflects a broader evolution in how decisions are made. Instead of reacting after the damage is done when obsolete parts are piling up or carbon disclosures are due leading manufacturers are embedding sustainability into everyday operations. That means identifying at-risk inventory before it becomes scrap, choosing fulfillment strategies that minimize emissions, and adjusting plans dynamically to reduce waste across the network. New digital capabilities are making this possible: - __Real-time visibility__ across supply, demand, and inventory positions, giving teams a unified picture of material movement and risk. - __AI-powered insights__ that detect waste patterns early, flag excess before it becomes obsolete, and identify opportunities to reduce emissions. - __Automated decision-making and execution__ that streamline routine actions like inventory redistribution or low-impact fulfillment routing. - __Scenario modeling tools__ that help planners weigh the environmental and financial outcomes of different options before committing resources. The result is a more sustainable supply chain not as a separate initiative, but as an integrated outcome of smarter, faster decisions. With these technologies in place, high-tech companies can track toward their ESG goals without adding complexity, slowing response times, or compromising financial performance. By replacing reactive processes with intelligent, real-time orchestration, the industry is proving that environmental responsibility and business agility dont have to be at odds. In fact, when decisions are powered by the right intelligence, they can strengthen each other. ### Powering Sustainable Supply Chains with Aera To help high-tech companies address these challenges, __Aera, the decision intelligence agent__, transforms waste management from a reactive burden into a proactive, strategic capability. Through real-time data, automated workflows, and predictive analytics, Aera delivers key capabilities through the following skills: - __Waste Prevention and Reduction Skill__ reduces scrap by identifying aging stock early and redirecting inventory before it expires. - __Demand Sensing and Smart Demand Shaping Skill__ aligns production more closely with actual consumption trends to minimize overproduction and excess. - __End-to-End Supply Chain Visibility and Risk Assessment Skill__ offers granular ESG insights, traceability, and emissions tracking, including Scope 3 visibility. Whether used individually or in combination, these skills empower high-tech manufacturers to take earlier, smarter action across the supply network. Instead of reacting to waste after it accumulates, companies can continuously monitor for risk, forecast more accurately, and reallocate resources before value is lost. For high-tech companies navigating the intersection of sustainability and operational performance, Aera delivers measurable outcomes. With these intelligent capabilities in place, businesses can: - __Cut waste by 1520%.__ - __Strengthen ESG compliance.__ - __Better align supply chain operations with long-term sustainability commitments.__ By embedding decision intelligence into daily operations, Aera helps organizations take control of their environmental footprint transforming waste management from a cost center into a driver of efficiency, resilience, and ESG leadership. ### Building Sustainable Performance with Decision Intelligence For high-tech manufacturers, reducing waste is about more than efficiency its central to sustainability, compliance, and long-term viability. But in a complex, fast-moving environment, traditional methods fall short. Waste accumulates. Reporting gaps widen. ESG goals slip further out of reach. Thats where decision intelligence comes in. Aera, helps companies act early, align operations with sustainability goals, and embed environmental responsibility into daily decisions. With skills like Waste Prevention and Reduction, Demand Sensing and Smart Demand Shaping, and End-to-End Supply Chain Visibility and Risk Assessment, Aera enables smarter, more timely actions that reduce waste and drive ESG performance. The result: a more sustainable, agile, and efficient supply chain. High-tech companies can cut waste, meet ESG targets, and create lasting value across their operations.

For more on how Aera can help you reduce waste and strengthen ESG performance across your supply chain, download the whitepaper, The AI Advantage: Powering the Future of High-Tech Supply Chains.

title.en-US: Webinar Recap: From Automation to Autonomy  Achieving Transformational Business Value with Agentic AI

content.en-US:
![Landing page (2)](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/2twkmx2QZg4IjDJ9tM93mA/02ef1039486c35c8bf50412b1df4ff5c/Landing_page__2_.jpg) ### Summary In our *Future.Now* webinar, __From Automation to Autonomy: Achieving Transformational Business Value with Agentic AI,__ we explored how leading enterprises are moving beyond routine automation to intent-driven, self-optimizing operations powered by Aera, the decision intelligence agent. Speakers from Accenture and Aera detailed why autonomy rather than incremental automation is now the fastest route to resilience, agility, and competitive advantage, especially in disruption-prone supply chains. Over the course of the session, they unpacked fresh findings from Accentures 2024 Autonomous Supply-Chain Global Survey, shared real-world examples in demand planning, inventory optimization, and promotion execution, and highlighted the architectural ingredients Decision Intelligence Networks and composable agent teams that allow autonomy to scale safely across complex global enterprises. ### Key Takeaways
  • Intent-driven operations now outperform function-driven processes.
    Autonomous agents translate high-level business goals (e.g., minimize stock-outs during a promotion) into coordinated, cross-functional actions, eliminating the silos and manual hand-offs that slow traditional process flows. This shift frees human experts to focus on strategy rather than transactional orchestration.
  • Fresh survey data underscores why autonomy cant wait.
    Accentures 2024 Autonomous Supply-Chain Global Survey reveals that more than 70 percent of supply-chain leaders deem autonomy mission-critical within three years, citing faster disruption recovery, greater forecast accuracy, and improved customer satisfaction as top drivers.
  • Early adopters are already posting eye-catching performance gains.
    Companies piloting agentic AI report a 60 percent reduction in time-to-recover from disruptions, a 22 percent drop in inventory without service loss, and 26 percent shorter product-development cycles benefits that cascade across the P&L.
  • A modular, agent-centric architecture turns vision into reality.
    Decision Intelligence Networks supply the trusted data fabric and governance layer, while small, composable teams of agents tackle discrete decision spaces (such as safety-stock setting or supplier reallocation) and learn from each other in real time, ensuring low risk and rapid time-to-value.
  • A staged, low-risk roadmap accelerates the ascent to full autonomy.
    Organizations typically progress from decision support to supervised automation and finally to full autonomy, where the agent senses risk, decides, and acts within policy limits delivering incremental ROI and building the trust needed for each successive leap.
### Speakers
Diego Pantoja-Navajas, Managing Director, Enterprise AI Value Strategy, Accenture
Diego leads Accentures global strategy for bringing agentic AI and decision intelligence into enterprise supply chains. Prior to Accenture, he founded cloud-native WMS pioneer LogFire (acquired by Oracle) and served as VP of AWS Supply Chain, where he helped shape SaaS execution and insight-driven operations.
Gonzalo Benedit, Chief Revenue Officer, Aera Technology
With two decades of experience guiding enterprise-software transformations, Gonzalo leads Aeras sales organization. Prior to Aera, he served as President of Workday International (EMEA & Asia) and held senior SAP posts, including COO for SAP EMEA and Managing Director for SAP Mexico.
Mustafa Kabul, SVP, Data Science & AI at Aera Technology
Mustafa drives the data-science and AI strategy behind Aera, blending optimization, machine learning, and generative AI to power autonomous decision-making. He earned a PhD in Operations Research from UNC-Chapel Hill, where his research focused on game-theoretic supply-chain models.
### Full Recording

Access the full webinar recording here.

### Q&A

Q: How do we decide when to use LLM agents or ML automation is there a simple framework?
Mustafa Kabul: Not a very simple framework. One danger in addressing these complex decision situations is to oversimplify the problems. The short answer is: it depends. It depends on the use case, the complexity of the use case, the complexity of the data, and the complexity of how we want to approach the problem. Is this a real-time scenario? Is this more of a decoupled, distributed batch scenario? A couple of principles: large-language-model agents are great at providing reasoning capabilities through a generative approach, and we can utilize large language models as general problem-solvers. When we equip them with advanced decision engines that can, at runtime, figure out which engine to use depending on the data and the character, the prompt of the agent we can address a variety of different complex scenarios. Traditional machine-learning models, on the other hand, are trained specifically for a given data task for example, a model that categorizes demand risk into three categories. You first have to acquire and build the training data for that specific task, train the model for that task and those categories, and then deploy it for runtime use. It isnt generalizable; as your data changes, you have to retrain it. The power of large language models is that they are very expressive, and their parameter space is very big. They can be adjusted for generic tasks by providing, even at inference time, examples to do some inference-time training adapting them to very different types of tasks.
Diego Pantoja-Navajas: And, Mustafa, if I can help: its more of an and than an or. Many processes still need statistical ML models. AI agents advance them further because NLP captures business nuances and relationships across the supply chain. In some cases, the ML models are helping us train the LLM models on the right tasks and goals so they continue to progress as they learn more about the business.
Mustafa Kabul: The good thing is, you have all that in Aera, the decision intelligence agent.
Diego Pantoja-Navajas: I love it and with Aera well move more companies to the right of the chart, growing the percentage that go from POC to fully autonomous supply chains. Congratulations love it.

Q: Do we need any foundational pieces like a data lake or planning system working well before we leverage agentic AI?
Diego Pantoja-Navajas: Thats a great question. Whole-supply-chain data foundation is, from my point of view, number one. Of course, you need the right direction and company alignment, but investing in a modern data foundation is critical. Without curated data one single version of truth and a fully connected data structure that brings data from structured and unstructured sources, you cant succeed. Once you think about the data foundation, you also need a semantic layer that translates tribal knowledge into a common vocabulary, and on top of that a knowledge layer that fuels our agents so they function optimally. Without that architecture, dont waste time trying to implement an agentic solution youll fail. I call it the data layer: sources, data products, semantic layer, knowledge layer. Make it number one on your to-do list as you move toward an autonomous supply chain.

Q: Weve heard a lot about agents hallucinating. How can this be prevented in such complex reasoning?
Diego Pantoja-Navajas: Dont try to boil the ocean. Build a north-star vision but hit minor milestones as you agentize workflows. Understand the data, reduce hallucinations, fail fast, go back, adjust, and build trust. Start small, have a solid data foundation, and be sure the agents have the right sources to execute successfully.
Mustafa Kabul: Thats fundamental. Implementing these powerful capabilities may require slower progression to understand every aspect. LLMs bring additional uncertainty. Your data foundation and deterministic agent functions must create a sandbox with validations and verifications. Work with a platform that sets the right data foundation and the right playground so LLM agents maximize their value.

Q: Dont agents take time to execute? How will this scale?
Mustafa Kabul: The compute-intensive jobs dont change. If youre solving a large mixed-integer linear program in your agentic workflow, the core math still runs at the same speed. The same goes for large-scale forecasting across millions of grains with deep-learning models. LLMs add latency when processing outputs interpreting and reasoning with inference but inference speeds are improving dramatically. The flexibility and time efficiency gained manual processes that took weeks become automated cover the added latency very quickly. Yes, theres some additional latency and maybe cost, but the benefits significantly outweigh that.
Diego Pantoja-Navajas: And the explainability the agents provide the what and the why adds huge value. Scaling with the right information and explainability is key, regardless of company size.

title.en-US: Increasing Revenue and Service Levels in High-Tech Supply Chains with Intelligent Component Allocation

content.en-US:
![Blog Hero Banner - Increasing Revenue in High-Tech Supply Chains](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/2N3Loda6SIMudNoKM9gFu6/4b3bd3b56eddfc02c2f5bf6dd0d0a699/Blog_Hero_Banner_-_Increasing_Revenue_in_High-Tech_Supply_Chains.jpg)

This is the fourth in a five-part series of blog posts on transforming high-tech supply chain operations with Aera, the decision intelligence agent.

### A Constraint-Driven Environment Demanding Smarter Allocation In high-tech supply chains, a single constrained component can jeopardize an entire product line, delay customer orders, or stall quarterly revenue targets. With thousands of parts feeding into increasingly complex product configurations, the margin for error is razor-thin. Chip shortages, supplier disruptions, and demand spikes can quickly lead to bottlenecks and missed opportunities. Yet traditional planning tools struggle to keep pace. Built around fixed rules and outdated snapshots, they leave teams relying on manual workarounds that are reactive at best. The result is limited visibility, suboptimal allocations, and strained service levels especially when demand outpaces constrained supply. This is where decision intelligence can make a critical difference. By applying real-time data, automation, and AI to the problem of component allocation, it enables high-tech manufacturers to make smarter, faster decisions that maximize available supply, protect revenue, and maintain customer trust. ### The Limits of Traditional Allocation in a Fast-Moving Market Todays high-tech supply chains operate in a world of constant disruption. Sudden shifts in demand, tight component supply, and escalating service expectations leave little room for error. Amid this volatility, the stakes have never been higher: a single allocation decision can impact product availability, customer satisfaction, and quarterly revenue all at once. Yet many high-tech companies still rely on outdated allocation models built for a more predictable era. These systems follow rigid logic, depend on stale data, and require manual intervention to reallocate supply. As a result, they simply cant respond with the speed or intelligence that modern supply chains demand. The consequences ripple across the organization: - __Shortages of critical components__ delay product deliveries and push out revenue recognition. - __Static allocation processes__ cant meet the speed, scale, or variability required by hyperscaler customers. - __Service disruptions__ erode trust and compromise long-term customer relationships. - __Planners must navigate conflicting goals__, balancing urgent demand with the realities of limited supply. - __Manual rebalancing__ often arrives too late, after the sales window closes or the opportunity disappears. In this environment, reacting after the fact is no longer enough. To compete, companies need real-time insight into where components are most needed, and the intelligence to make profitable allocation decisions on the fly. Without it, theyre left with guesswork, missed targets, and rising costs. ### How the Industry Is Responding: Smarter, Faster Allocation at Scale To keep up with shifting demand and constrained supply, high-tech leaders are investing in a new generation of tools built on real-time data, AI, and automation. These technologies offer a step change from traditional allocation models, replacing lagging, rules-based processes with systems that sense change early, evaluate trade-offs quickly, and respond automatically. The result is faster execution, better service levels, and greater alignment between supply chain actions and business priorities. Across the industry, these innovations are helping companies move from reactive allocation to proactive, strategic execution. Whether allocating chips across regions, balancing components among product lines, or adapting to a sudden customer need, supply chain teams now have access to smarter, more scalable capabilities that reduce manual effort and improve decision quality at speed and scale. Some of the new capabilities powering this transformation include: - __Real-time visibility__ across supply, demand, and inventory positions, giving teams a comprehensive view of material movement, production capacity, and fulfillment risk. - __AI-powered insights__ that flag allocation mismatches early, anticipate demand shifts, and recommend adjustments to protect revenue and customer relationships. - __Automated decisioning and execution__ that replaces time-consuming manual processes with intelligent workflows, accelerating allocation and minimizing human error. - __Scenario modeling tools__ that allow planners to assess the financial, operational, and service-level implications of different strategies before committing resources. These capabilities are helping companies break out of reactive firefighting mode and build a more adaptive approach to allocation one thats anchored in data, aligned with business priorities, and responsive to ongoing disruption. More importantly, theyre enabling operations and supply chain teams to collaborate in real time, weigh trade-offs more effectively, and execute allocation strategies that drive both performance and profitability. What was once a static, resource-intensive function is becoming a continuous, intelligence-driven capability. ### Maximizing Revenue and Service Impact with Aera To help high-tech companies overcome the limits of traditional allocation, __Aera, the decision intelligence agent__, delivers a smarter way to match constrained supply with real-time demand. Instead of relying on static rules or manual workarounds, Aera continuously monitors supply conditions, customer needs, and production capacity to dynamically allocate scarce components where theyll have the greatest impact. The result is faster, more accurate decision-making that protects revenue, improves service levels, and keeps pace with a volatile market. At the core of Aeras allocation solution are three specialized skills, each designed to address a different facet of the supply-demand equation: - __Intelligent Chip and Critical Component Allocation Skill__ dynamically reallocates scarce parts to the products, customers, and geographies where theyll deliver the greatest revenue and service value. - __Demand Sensing and Smart Demand Shaping Skill__ anticipates demand shifts before they materialize and informs allocation strategies to ensure supply aligns with actual market needs. - __Dynamic Inventory Balancing and Reallocation Skill__ matches available inventory to top customer and channel priorities, helping protect key accounts and minimize revenue leakage. Whether used individually or in combination, these skills give high-tech companies the control and flexibility to navigate ongoing volatility, while protecting growth, customer satisfaction, and brand reputation. When limited inventory and growing complexity threaten performance, Aera helps high-tech manufacturers turn challenge into opportunity. With these capabilities, they can: - __Capture 515% more revenue__ by allocating constrained components where they have the highest impact. - __Increase service reliability__ by responding faster to real-time risks and shifts in demand. - __Safeguard key accounts__ by prioritizing high-value orders and strategic customers. With Aeras decision intelligence embedded into daily operations, high-tech supply chains can act with the speed and precision that todays market demands, ensuring that limited supply never limits success. ### Smarter Allocation, Agility, and Growth with Decision Intelligence In high-tech supply chains, agility is everything. Success depends not only on allocating scarce components effectively, but also on anticipating demand shifts and dynamically rebalancing inventory to stay aligned with customer and market needs. When supply conditions shift, the ability to act quickly can make or break performance. Thats the advantage Aera brings as the decision intelligence agent: faster, smarter decisions across the allocation lifecycle that adapt to change in real time. With intelligent capabilities that prioritize critical components, sense shifting demand, and dynamically rebalance inventory, Aera helps high-tech companies stay ahead of disruption and deliver at scale. This is the power of decision intelligence in action: continuous, connected decision-making that helps high-tech businesses improve service, capture more revenue, and operate with greater precision.

For more on how Aera can help you increase revenue and improve service through smarter component allocation, download the whitepaper, The AI Advantage: Powering the Future of High-Tech Supply Chains

title.en-US: Driving Decision Intelligence in Clinical Supply Chains: A Joint Perspective from ZS and Aera Technology

content.en-US:
![Blog Hero Banner - Driving Decision Intelligence in Clinical Supply Chains](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/2SCmdrQBjHXz87UVdeXT9h/51c904d7b6760261ed6b23e6735b4506/Blog_Hero_Banner_-_Driving_Decision_Intelligence_in_Clinical_Supply_Chains.jpg)

### Why We Wrote This

As consultants and technology providers immersed in supply chain transformation, we hear the same question from every life sciences client: *How do we keep up with the rising complexity of clinical trials without endlessly adding people and inventory?*

That challenge shaped our latest collaboration with a global biopharmaceutical leaders clinical supply team. In this post, we reflect on how ZS and Aera Technology partnered to bring decision intelligence to life, sharing why it matters, how we deployed it in record time, and what others in the industry can learn from the journey.

### From DataRich to DecisionReady

The pharma industry is undergoing a period of change, where the number of trials has increased significantly over the last 2-3 years. To meet this increase in the number of trials, along with the complexity of modalities, clinical supply organizations significantly increase headcount to keep up with demand. While this growth reflects a thriving R&D pipeline, it has also surfaced a core tension: manual ways of working cannot keep pace with increasing demand volatility. In addition to the increased demand, theres growing pressure to reduce waste  its very common for more than 50% of packed products to end up in the bins!

In our clients case, it was clear that scaling through people alone was not sustainable. Together, ZS and Aera Technology proposed a new approach: *scale decision intelligence and create a digital workforce*.

For this pharma company, the decision intelligence journey began with a crucial first step: making the data usable. Like many global organizations, our client was rich in data but faced challenges with fragmentation and inconsistency. Clean, joinable data was essential. Before activating __Aera, the decision intelligence agent__, the clinical supply team launched a data excellence initiative that governed critical datasets to make them AI-ready. That investment laid the foundation for rapid progress.

### How We Made It Real

__Clarify the North Star.__ We began with a four-day decision theater workshop, bringing together business, IT, and quality leaders to align on the outcomes that matter most: improved productivity, reduced waste, and uninterrupted patient supply. These priorities grounded every decision that followed.

__Launch fast.__ Within just three months, the first live Aera Skill was deployed, freeing analysts from time-intensive data wrangling and accelerating action. The teams energy was palpable, marked by what are now fondly remembered as Aera parties  internal events that introduced the concept of a digital coworker and helped build engagement and excitement.

__Demonstrate impact early.__ One of the first real-world wins came when a delay was flagged that could have resulted in rescheduling a cancer patients visit. Because the delay was flagged early to the right team, a decision was made to expedite the shipment, ensuring the patient stayed on protocol. Moments like this turned abstract value into tangible outcomes, boosting support across the organization.

__Link every use case to data excellence.__ Every new skill was paired with KPIs for data quality, ensuring stewardship efforts directly contributed to business outcomes. That discipline created a virtuous cycle: better data enabling better decisions, which in turn fueled further investment in data maturity.

### Five Takeaways for the LifeSciences Community

For organizations just beginning their decision intelligence journey, a few guiding principles emerged:

- __Start small, scale quickly.__ A single high-impact skill can shift mindsets and spark enterprise-wide momentum.
- __Treat data like a product.__ Data governance may not be glamorous, but it's the fuel for every intelligent decision.
- __Blend expertise from day one.__ Pair business domain leaders with technologists and data stewards to co-create scalable solutions.
- __Make change tangible  and fun.__ Live demos, peer testimonials, and yes, even parties, help bring transformation to life.
- __Measure what matters.__ Link every skill to hard KPIs  cycle time, waste, stock-outs  so stakeholders can see value early and often.

### Whats Next

This is just the beginning. With more Aera Skills rolling out later this year, our client expects to unlock further cost savings, increase efficiency, and  most importantly  protect every trial participant from preventable supply disruptions.

Decision intelligence isnt just about automation. Its about changing how decisions are made  introducing new workflows, data inputs, and organizational capabilities that drive faster, more confident action.

If youre ready to explore what that could look like for your organization, connect with our joint ZSAera team. Lets turn your data into decisions that move at the speed of science.

title.en-US: Supply Chain Waste Prevention, Reimagined: Decision Intelligence in Action

content.en-US:
![Blog Hero Banner - Supply Chain Waste Prevention, Reimagined](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/4dz8QsVkSRZgYnG5Od5Y8I/cf559ff633a226dc7db3a4b62e50d93d/Blog_Hero_Banner_-_Supply_Chain_Waste_Prevention__Reimagined.jpg) Excess and obsolete (E&O) inventory is a persistent challenge across supply chains, locking up capital, driving write-offs, and inflating waste. As product portfolios expand and demand grows less predictable, inventory often exceeds whats needed or expires before it can be used. And its not just a financial issue. E&O inventory undermines sustainability goals by increasing emissions, contributing to landfill, and inflating Scope 3 carbon impacts. In todays environment of heightened accountability, managing waste is an enterprise imperative. Thats why many organizations are turning to decision intelligence. By embedding real-time, context-aware intelligence into inventory operations, it enables earlier risk detection, smarter mitigation, and faster action. The result: a leaner, more resilient supply chain that prevents waste before it happens. ### Why Traditional Approaches Fall Short Legacy approaches to managing excess and obsolescence rely heavily on static business rules, delayed reporting cycles, and manual triage. These methods cant keep up with modern supply chain complexity. Volatile demand, long lead times, and fast-changing product lifecycles demand faster, more context-aware decisions. Traditional E&O mitigation suffers from three critical gaps: - __Lack of real-time visibility:__ Emerging risks go undetected until its too late. - __Static logic:__ Fixed thresholds cant adapt to shifting conditions like seasonality or changing lead times. - __Siloed accountability:__ Mitigation falls through the cracks without clear ownership or coordinated action. As a result, inventory write-offs remain high, and the opportunity to act before loss occurs is often missed. ### The Case for Decision Intelligence A smarter, more proactive approach is needed. Thats where decision intelligence comes in. Aera, the decision intelligence agent built on Aera Decision Cloud, enables organizations to move from reactive mitigation to intelligent prevention of waste. Using the __Waste Prevention and Reduction Skill__, Aera transforms how companies detect risk, evaluate options, and execute mitigation actions in real time and at scale. Instead of waiting for a problem to surface in a report, Aera continuously monitors supply, demand, production, and inventory data to identify risks as they emerge. It then simulates mitigation options, recommends the most effective course of action, and enables execution, all while keeping human decision-makers in control. ### A Closed-Loop System for Smarter Inventory Management Leveraging the Waste Prevention and Reduction Skill, Aera follows a six-step process that connects data, intelligence, and action: 1. __Unified data foundation:__ Aera integrates planning, demand, supply, shelf-life, and financial data across the enterprise to create a SKU-level view of E&O risk. 2. __Trigger detection:__ Automated logic surfaces early warnings such as forecast mismatches, aging inventory, or velocity declines before loss occurs. 3. __Context-aware simulation:__ AI/ML models evaluate mitigation options such as reallocation, production throttling, or demand shaping, scoring each based on financial, operational, and environmental impact. 4. __Action recommendation:__ Next best actions are ranked and explained with clear rationale, and tailored to personas like planners, procurement leads, and category managers. 5. __Execution enablement:__ Approved actions flow directly into enterprise systems for execution, tracked in real time with full visibility. 6. __Continuous learning:__ Every action becomes input for system learning, improving accuracy, speed, and decision quality over time. This isnt just automation. Its intelligent orchestration a closed loop that turns insight into impact while continuously learning and improving. ### Real-World Results at Scale Aeras customers are seeing measurable gains across key performance indicators: - __$50M$200M in working capital released__ by reducing excess inventory holdings - __13% improvement in gross margin__ through proactive write-off prevention - __7590% reduction in manual triage time__ for supply planners and inventory managers - __Tangible ESG impact__, including waste avoidance and reduced Scope 3 emissions These arent isolated wins; theyre systemic improvements across operations, finance, and sustainability. ### Empowering the People Behind the Decisions While Aera delivers automation at scale, its built around human judgment. Business users define decision thresholds, review recommendations, and configure the level of automation based on confidence and risk. The platform is explainable, auditable, and fully transparent designed to build trust, not replace expertise. Heres how it transforms work across the enterprise: - __Planners and inventory managers__ spend less time on manual tracking and more time executing strategic actions. - __Procurement teams__ adjust supplier orders before excess builds up, reducing stranded materials and unneeded spend. - __Category and business unit leaders__ gain early visibility into risk and trade-off scenarios across cost, service, and ESG metrics. - __Finance and sustainability teams__ track avoided waste, emissions savings, and real-time exposure, shifting from reactive reporting to operational influence. This cross-functional approach creates a shared framework where everyone sees the same data, interprets the same logic, and drives toward the same goals: reduced loss, better margins, and smarter sustainability. ### Human + AI: Smarter Decisions, Together At the core of decision intelligence is a powerful partnership: AI for scale and speed, humans for insight and control. Aera brings this collaboration to life through its Waste Prevention and Reduction Skill, aligning teams across planning, procurement, finance, and sustainability to manage inventory risk more effectively. The agent continuously detects risk signals and simulates mitigation options, then delivers contextual, ranked recommendations that users can review and act on. But the real differentiator is flexibility: business teams define the decision logic, thresholds, and automation rules, ensuring the system works the way the organization does. Over time, Aera learns from every action and outcome. Accepted, modified, or rejected recommendations all feed back into the intelligence layer, improving future precision and impact. The result is a self-improving system that amplifies the best of both human and machine, speeding up response times while keeping strategic control firmly in human hands. ### A Blueprint for Zero-Waste Inventory As supply chains become more interconnected and sustainability expectations rise, the need for intelligent, forward-looking systems is only increasing. Aera helps companies shift from firefighting to foresight, from loss prevention to strategic advantage. Imagine a supply chain that: - Predicts excess risk before it materializes - Executes routine mitigation autonomously - Aligns decisions with environmental and financial KPIs - Learns and improves with every action taken Thats the future Aera is enabling. And with decision intelligence, that future is no longer out of reach its actionable today.

Ready to reduce excess, protect margin, and drive sustainable operations? Download the full whitepaper, From Waste, Excess, and Obsolescence to Intelligent Inventory Management, to learn how Aera can help your organization take control of inventory risk and turn it into an opportunity for growth and impact.

title.en-US: Boosting Efficiency and Reducing Planner Effort in High-Tech Supply Chains Using Decision Intelligence

content.en-US:
![Blog Author Banner - Reducing Planner Effort in High-Tech Supply Chains](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/43GbrslUQsNlvnFxwbSrwt/53276f89d77f0aec212230391b9d189c/Blog_Hero_Banner_-_Reducing_Planner_Effort_in_High-Tech_Supply_Chains.jpg)

This is the fifth in a five-part series of blog posts on transforming high-tech supply chain operations with Aera, the decision intelligence agent.

### An Overloaded Function in an Increasingly Complex Environment In high-tech supply chains, planners are under growing pressure to deliver speed, precision, and resilience all at once. But as supply networks expand and product complexity intensifies, so does the volume and volatility of decisions theyre expected to manage. From demand shifts to supplier changes, every fluctuation adds to a constant stream of choices that need to be made quickly, accurately, and at scale. Traditional tools arent built for this level of complexity. They rely on static inputs and disconnected workflows, forcing planners to chase down data, juggle priorities, and fill in the gaps manually. The result? Inefficiencies multiply, responsiveness suffers, and strategic focus gets lost in the day-to-day firefighting. This is where decision intelligence provides a smarter path forward. By continuously ingesting real-time data, learning from historical patterns, and automating routine decisions, it gives high-tech manufacturers a smarter, faster way to streamline planning reducing effort, improving execution, and freeing up time for higher-value work. ### The Cost of Inefficiency in High-Tech Planning High-tech supply chains run at extraordinary speed and scale. Every day, planners must juggle thousands of decisions, from resolving shortages and reallocating inventory to balancing service levels across regions and customers. The pace is relentless, and the margin for error is slim. Here, even minor delays or inefficiencies can quickly snowball, cutting into productivity and performance. Yet many organizations still rely on tools and processes designed for simpler times. Traditional planning systems depend on disconnected data, rigid rules, and limited automation. Instead of easing the burden, they force planners into constant firefighting mode. The result is slower response, higher risk, and mounting strain on the people responsible for keeping supply chains moving. These challenges extend across teams and functions: - __Repetitive manual work__ consumes planners time, leaving them buried in tasks like resolving shortages, chasing down exceptions, and manually reallocating inventory. - __Disconnected systems__ create data silos, requiring hours of collection and reconciliation before meaningful action can even begin. - __Reactive workflows__ delay response times, introduce errors, and prevent planners from staying ahead of fast-changing conditions. - __Strategic planning suffers__, as talent is pulled away from long-term optimization to manage daily operational crises. - __Talent shortages intensify fatigue__, with unsustainable workloads making it harder to attract and retain skilled planners. In this environment, inefficiency is more than an inconvenience its a competitive disadvantage. Without real-time insight, seamless integration, and intelligent automation, companies remain stuck in reactive mode, unable to scale planning effectiveness or free their teams to focus on higher-value work. ### How the Industry Is Responding: Smarter, More Sustainable Planning at Scale To ease the strain on planners and address mounting inefficiencies, high-tech leaders are embracing real-time data, AI, and automation. These technologies represent a step change from the legacy tools that depend on outdated snapshots and manual inputs. Instead of reacting after the fact, companies can now sense changes early, evaluate options quickly, and automate repetitive tasks reducing workload while improving decision accuracy. Across the industry, this shift is transforming planning from a manual, error-prone process into a more adaptive, intelligence-driven capability. Whether resolving shortages, reallocating inventory, or managing exceptions, supply chain teams are leveraging new digital capabilities to lighten planner workloads, accelerate execution, and create room for more strategic focus. Some of the new capabilities powering this transformation include: - __Real-time visibility__ into demand, supply, and inventory positions, giving planners a single source of truth for faster, more confident decisions. - __AI-driven insights__ that detect inefficiencies, flag risks early, and recommend the best course of action before issues escalate. - __Automated workflows__ that eliminate repetitive tasks like shortage resolution, allocation adjustments, and exception handling, cutting response times dramatically. - __Scenario modeling__ that allows teams to test alternative strategies and understand their financial and service-level implications in advance. Together, these capabilities are helping companies shift from firefighting to foresight empowering planners to work more efficiently, collaborate more effectively, and deliver stronger business outcomes at scale. What was once an exhausting, resource-heavy process is evolving into a smarter, self-improving system of execution. ### Boosting Efficiency and Reducing Planner Workload with Aera To help high-tech companies overcome the inefficiencies of traditional planning, __Aera, the decision intelligence agent__, delivers a smarter way to manage supply chains at scale. Instead of depending on fragmented systems or manual interventions, Aera integrates real-time visibility, AI-powered insights, and automation to streamline operations and ease the burden on planners. The result is faster, more efficient decision-making that reduces manual effort, expands planner capacity, and keeps supply chains aligned with business priorities. At the core of Aeras solution are three specialized skills, each designed to target a critical aspect of supply chain efficiency: - __End-to-End Supply Chain Visibility and Risk Assessment Skill__ provides a single, actionable view of supply, demand, and risk factors eliminating the hours planners spend gathering and reconciling data. - __Dynamic Inventory Balancing and Reallocation Skill__ automates routine rebalancing and shortage handling, lightening planner workloads while ensuring inventory flows to the highest-priority needs. - __Waste Prevention and Reduction Skill__ proactively flags risks and applies intelligent automation to reduce exception handling and protect against costly inefficiencies. Whether deployed individually or together, these skills allow planners to work more strategically, reduce firefighting, and improve supply chain performance. For high-tech organizations grappling with rising decision volume and limited resources, Aera delivers measurable results. With these intelligent capabilities in place, businesses can: - __Reduce manual planning effort__ by 2030% - __Expand planner capacity__ to focus on strategic priorities - __Improve responsiveness__ while reducing operational strain By embedding decision intelligence into daily operations, Aera transforms planning from a reactive, manual exercise into a more efficient, rewarding, and impactful role. With automation and real-time insights, teams can spend less time on routine tasks and more time driving innovation, growth, and resilience. ### Smarter Planning, Efficiency, and Growth with Decision Intelligence For high-tech supply chains, efficiency has become the new competitive edge. Success depends not only on having the right data, but also on reducing the manual effort that slows down planners and limits agility. When decision volume is rising and complexity is accelerating, relying on human bandwidth alone is no longer sustainable. Thats the advantage Aera brings as the decision intelligence agent: faster, more efficient decisions across the planning lifecycle that automate routine work, surface risks early, and empower teams to focus on higher-value priorities. With intelligent capabilities that unify visibility, automate rebalancing, and proactively mitigate risks, Aera helps planners work smarter and organizations scale with confidence. This is the power of decision intelligence in action: continuous, connected decision-making that reduces workload, improves efficiency, and frees supply chain talent to drive growth and innovation.

For more on how Aera can help you boost efficiency and reduce planner effort across your supply chain, download the whitepaper, The AI Advantage: Powering the Future of High-Tech Supply Chains.

title.en-US: Balancing Speed with Safety in Clinical Trials Using Decision Intelligence

content.en-US:
![Blog Hero Banner - Balancing Speed with Safety in Clinical Trials](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/3hFqOTItwThaYTODNUSR9s/c7bf94f38373dadef51bda3a0fd930f1/Blog_Hero_Banner_-_Balancing_Speed_with_Safety_in_Clinical_Trials.jpg)

This is the fifth in a five-part series of blog posts on transforming pharmaceutical and life-science supply chain operations with Aera, the decision intelligence agent.

### An Industry Caught Between Urgency and Oversight Clinical trials are growing in scale and complexity. Many pharmaceutical companies now manage hundreds of studies simultaneously, spanning global sites and diverse patient populations. With so much at stake, even minor delays can cost millions and delay the delivery of life-changing therapies. Timelines are tightening, expectations are rising, and trial teams are being asked to do more with less. Yet most clinical operations still rely on fragmented systems and manual coordination, making it difficult to act quickly without compromising safety, compliance, or data quality. Even when visibility exists, its often passive, highlighting issues without the tools to resolve them at speed or scale. The result is an environment defined by trade-offs: accelerate execution or ensure protocol adherence; improve site performance or reduce operational risk. Forward-looking companies are recognizing that it doesnt have to be either-or. Enter decision intelligence: a new approach that empowers trial teams to move faster, act sooner, and make better-informed choices without compromising safety or control. ### The Operational Hurdles Slowing Clinical Trial Progress Pharmaceutical companies are scaling up their clinical development pipelines running more trials, across more sites, with higher complexity. But executing at speed while maintaining quality, safety, and compliance is proving difficult. The goals are clear: accelerate development, ensure patient safety, and streamline costs. In practice, however, these priorities are often in conflict. Six persistent challenges illustrate why: - __Manual Enrollment and Site Activation.__ Recruiting patients and activating sites still rely on manual coordination, paper documentation, and disjointed workflows. These inefficiencies delay trial starts, increase dropout risk, and lengthen timelines. - __Cumbersome Trial Execution.__ From site monitoring to data verification, many core processes remain administrative and repetitive. Study teams spend hours reconciling data, responding to issues, and filling communication gaps time that could be focused on patients and outcomes. - __Disconnected Supply Chain Operations.__ Coordinating drug supply across global sites requires precise timing, accurate forecasting, and tight chain-of-custody control. But limited visibility into site-level inventory often leads to stockouts, temperature excursions, or excess waste each with direct patient impact. - __Fragmented and Inaccurate Data.__ Clinical operations depend on data from multiple systems electronic data capture (EDC) software, clinical trial management systems (CTMS), interactive response technology (IRT), and beyond. But these systems rarely speak the same language. Discrepancies between platforms require manual reconciliation and slow decisions that should be made in real time. - __Limited Predictive Capabilities.__ Without visibility into future enrollment patterns or evolving site needs, teams are left reacting to problems instead of anticipating them. Quality issues, shipment delays, and enrollment shortfalls are often flagged too late to prevent costly disruptions. - __Rigid Scenario Planning.__ Adjusting trial design or supply strategies midstream is difficult. Most teams lack tools to test alternative approaches, such as protocol amendments or site resource shifts, and quickly understand the impact on timelines, budgets, and inventory. These hurdles cant be solved with spreadsheets or oversight alone. Whats needed is a smarter way to manage complexity, one that unifies operational and clinical data, automates time-consuming processes, and enables faster, more informed decisions at every step of the trial journey. ### How the Industry Is Responding: Moving Clinical Trials from Reactive to Predictive To overcome these challenges, pharmaceutical organizations are rethinking how clinical trials are managed shifting from reactive coordination to predictive, intelligence-led execution. Instead of relying solely on manual oversight and retrospective reporting, leading companies are using real-time data, AI, and automation to drive smarter decisions across the trial lifecycle. Next-generation platforms are making it possible to unify data from clinical, operational, and supply systems, breaking down silos and enabling faster, clearer action. AI helps identify potential risks early, from enrollment bottlenecks to inventory shortfalls. And automation removes the burden of repetitive tasks, allowing teams to focus on safety, strategy, and outcomes. Crucially, these capabilities arent just improving speed; theyre enhancing confidence and control. By embedding intelligence directly into the workflows that support trial planning, execution, and supply, pharmaceutical companies can: - Accelerate patient enrollment and site activation - Predict drug demand based on real-time trial activity - Avoid stockouts or overages through smarter allocation - Reduce delays caused by data errors or fragmented systems - Adjust trial operations in-flight, with full visibility into impact This represents more than just process improvement. Its a fundamental step toward making clinical trials more adaptive, efficient, and patient-centered without compromising on quality or compliance. ### Streamlining Clinical Trial Supply Chains with Aera As pharmaceutical companies work to manage increasingly complex clinical trials with greater speed and precision, Aera, the decision intelligence agent, stands out as a solution purpose-built for the challenge. Rather than relying on manual coordination or disconnected planning systems, the agent embeds real-time intelligence directly into supply chain workflows, enabling teams to manage complexity with speed, confidence, and control. At the core of Aeras approach are prebuilt, domain-specific skills AI-powered capabilities that continuously analyze data, learn from evolving trial dynamics, and automate high-impact decisions. These skills replace time-consuming activities like manual data aggregation and one-off analyses with continuous, proactive insights. For pharmaceutical companies managing global trials across thousands of sites, several skills drive especially meaningful results: - __Supplier and CMO Decision Center__ monitors supplier and contract manufacturing organization (CMO) system data to identify risks before they disrupt supply. It recommends adjustments to orders or production schedules, and highlights performance issues, helping sponsors proactively mitigate risks that could delay or derail trials. - __Production and Packaging Decision Center__ analyzes production and packaging data across facilities, uncovering inefficiencies and recommending schedule changes, process improvements, and interventions to meet trial demand with greater precision. - __Distribution Decision Center__ monitors logistics activity across the network, flagging delays, bottlenecks, or routing issues. It recommends optimized inventory placement, smarter transport planning, and delivery routes that reduce both cost and carbon emissions. - __Last Mile Decision Center__ focuses on the clinical sites themselves, identifying underperforming trials, stock imbalances, and potential delays. It recommends actions such as expediting deliveries, reallocating inventory, or adjusting recruitment strategies to ensure trial continuity. Together, these capabilities form an intelligent layer across the clinical trial supply chain. Instead of reacting to issues after they happen, pharmaceutical companies gain the ability to anticipate them and resolve them before timelines slip or costs escalate. The impact is clear: - __Increased productivity__ by automating complex trial operations without increasing headcount - __Faster launches__ through proactive planning that reduces delays and accelerates time to market - __Lower expedited shipping costs__ by improving forecast accuracy and logistics execution - __Reduced waste and emissions__ by consolidating shipments and minimizing overproduction - __Improved success rates__ through predictive planning that keeps trials on track - __Knowledge retention and reuse__ by documenting decision outcomes to improve future planning This isnt just smarter planning; its a smarter way of working. Aera gives trial teams the tools to move faster, allocate resources more effectively, and keep their focus where it matters most: delivering safe, timely, and successful clinical trials. ### The Case for Decision Intelligence in Clinical Trials For pharmaceutical companies, balancing speed and safety in clinical trials is no longer an abstract goal its an urgent, everyday challenge. But with trials growing in scale, complexity, and scrutiny, traditional systems and reactive processes are no longer enough to keep up. Aera offers a new path forward. By embedding decision intelligence directly into trial operations, the agent empowers teams to make faster, more accurate, and more proactive decisions all while reducing risk, improving compliance, and staying aligned with clinical and business objectives. With AI-powered skills that streamline execution, optimize supply strategies, and respond to issues in real time, Aera enables companies to conduct trials with greater precision, resilience, and confidence. Its not just about accelerating progress; its about doing so without compromise.

For more on how Aera can help you build smarter, faster, and more patient-focused clinical trials, download the whitepaper, Prescription for Excellence: Decision Intelligence in Modern Pharmaceutical Operations.

title.en-US: Smarter Price Forecasting for Better Procurement Decisions

content.en-US:
![Hero image (1) (1)](//images.ctfassets.net/mh1amgo8m7ts/2KLDusEcZUq0wFKjXjQwwZ/1573033868b3878f5efa92c02e526aa2/Hero_image__1___1_.jpg)

This blog is part of an ongoing series exploring how Aera Skills solve real-world supply chain challenges.

Accurate price forecasting is critical for effective procurement planning yet many organizations struggle to achieve it consistently. Thats where AI and automation can help, providing the support needed to generate more reliable forecasts, reduce manual effort, and lower procurement risk. With the __Procurement Price Forecasting Skill__, the Aera decision intelligence agent has achieved 99% forecast coverage, cut manual effort by more than 90%, and improved forecast accuracy to above 85%. These results enable procurement teams to plan with greater confidence, move faster, and focus on strategic, data-driven decision-making instead of reactive firefighting. ### The Challenges: Incomplete Data, Manual Work, and Planning Risk Many organizations still rely on manual workarounds and inconsistent data when building their price forecasts. These stopgaps introduce risk, delay planning cycles, and increase operational cost especially for long-tail or newly introduced items. Common challenges include: - __Incomplete price forecasts__ for specific material-site combinations, particularly low-frequency items. - __Complex data management__, with outdated or partial contract data that requires time-consuming manual cleanup. - __No reliable forecasts for new materials__, where historical pricing simply doesnt exist. - __Manual similarity mapping__, where teams rely on subjective judgment to match materials an error-prone approach that doesnt scale. Left unaddressed, these issues slow procurement cycles, undermine supplier negotiations, and elevate risk in financial planning. ### The Aera Solution: AI-Driven Forecasting at Scale Aera, the decision intelligence agent, uses the Procurement Price Forecasting Skill to automate and enhance the forecasting process from end to end. This capability transforms procurement planning into a data-driven, intelligent system of action by: - __Smartly grouping materials__ based on the availability of pricing data full, partial, or none. - __Applying tailored forecasting logic__ using the most appropriate model for each group: time series models for historical data, regression for partial data, and NLP-based similarity matching for new materials. - __Generating context-rich forecasts__ by integrating contract terms, pricing, currency, and other relevant data. - __Writing forecasts directly into planning and transactional systems__, enabling real-time use and operational alignment. Aera combines a range of advanced AI techniques including Holt-Winters, ARIMA, TF-IDF, cosine similarity, and multidimensional analysis to ensure that every material is forecasted with the right approach. This reduces uncertainty while eliminating reliance on manual judgment. ### Case Study: From Planning Bottlenecks to Forecasting Confidence A leading consumer packaged goods (CPG) company had long struggled with incomplete material price forecasts. Planning delays, uncertainty in supplier negotiations, and elevated cost risks were common. Manual workarounds for missing or inconsistent data only made matters worse, particularly for long-tail items where historical context was sparse. After deploying Aera with the Procurement Price Forecasting Skill, the company automated its forecasting process, applied AI-driven models suited to each data scenario, and pushed accurate, site-level forecasts directly into its planning systems. Within just a few months, the results were transformative: - __99%__ forecast coverage across the material line - __>90%__ reduction in manual effort - __>85%__ forecast accuracy These improvements accelerated planning cycles, supported more confident supplier negotiations, and significantly reduced procurement risk. ### Why Aera: What Sets It Apart Aera transforms procurement forecasting from a manual, error-prone task into a streamlined, intelligent process powered by AI and automation. It replaces complexity and guesswork with speed, accuracy, and consistency, so teams can focus on making better decisions, not managing data. - __Unified decision intelligence__: Aera integrates data harmonization, forecasting logic, and intelligent matching into a single solution. - __AI-augmented workflows__: It improves procurement efficiency with composite AI and machine learning across the full procurement lifecycle. - __Closed-loop execution__: Forecasts are automatically pushed into operational systems, accelerating and standardizing decisions at scale. With Aera, procurement teams can move beyond reactive work and toward strategic, data-driven decision-making confident that their forecasts are accurate, timely, and actionable. ### Ready to transform your procurement forecasting?

For more on how Aera can help you achieve comprehensive forecast coverage, eliminate manual effort, and reduce procurement risk, download the Procurement Price Forecasting Skill brief or schedule a demo.
